Play details
Captaine Thomas Stuckeley. Genre: History. Date first published: 1605. Date first performed: 11 Dec 1596.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Captain Thomas Stuckeley Wife of Curteis Alderman Curteis Nell, daughter of Curteis Old Maister Stuckeley Hamdon Ridley Captain Harbart Curteis Cashier Hazzard Crack Blurt Gainsford Newton, a citizen Thomas Thumpe Page Sparing, the Vintner Cross, the Mercer Spring, the Vintner Sharp, the Cutler Blunt, the Buckler Vernon another Captain Combined speech Lieutenant Ensign Shane O'Neale O Hamlon Neale Makener Soldier Alexander Gillian Buske Govenor Govenor's wife servant Provost King Phillip Bottellio Alva Sancto Davila Herando Lantardo Ship Master Nuntio Valdes Sebastian Antonio Cardinal Chorus Muly Mahamet Calipolis Abdelmeleck Hamet Avaro 1 Turkish soldier 2 Turkish soldier 1 Italian soldier 2 Italian soldier

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Proceed son Vernon, on with your discourse.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Curteis, spare that name of son. I must confess I should have been your Son, and had thereto your Wives and your consent.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: And had son Vernon, Aye and so have still?
Bones a Dod man, if I be a Knight,
Sir Thomas Curtise, and an Alderman.
they that say deny my Daughter is not yours?
Roundly off.
by ye and nay I think them not my friends,
Passion of me man, not my Daughter yours?
What say you wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Husband what should I say,
Is it not known through London, do not our friends
daily expect the marriage of our child,
to master Vernon here? and ask ye me,
what say you wife?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Why heard ye not his words,
he must confess he should have been our Son:
and thereto had both your consent and mine?
have you denied him since. Passion of me,
Besse, and Son both, these speeches make me muse
not have our Daughter.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Husband, husband, perhaps his mind is changed,
or our girls portion is not great enough,
and therefore now he seeks to break it off.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Sits the wind there wife? ha, think ye so?
by yea and nay, then wife he deals not well.
Come roundly roundly come, what is the matter?
passion of me, break off, and for no cause? ha?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir Thomas patience but yourself awhile.
and you shall see, that mere necessity
breaks off our match.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: On then a Gods name,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I doubt not, but by marriage of your child,
you seek such comforts as the sacred state,
yields you as parents, us as children?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: what else Son Vernon?
And those high blessings, no way are attained,
but by the mutual sympathising love,
that as combining hands so should the hearts,
of either party, else it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: all this is true Son Vernon.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: now then Sir Thomas, you cannot expect
these comforts by our matches on neither part
If you give me her hand and not her heart,
The one I know you may, compulsively.
the other never but unwillingly

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Bones of dod man, how? what have we here?
her hand and not her heart. Nell, come hither Nell,
passion of me wench, how comes this to pass
we point ye one, you love another, ha?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: May this be so maid, ha? why speak ye not.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Madam, and good Sir Thomas be not rough
with your fair daughter, what her bashfulness
conceals from you, favour me to disclose
See ye this Gentleman here master Stukley?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: O master Stukly a courteous Gentleman, what of him?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: he is the substance of my shadowed love,
I but a Cipher, in respect of him.
you give me your consent, but he gains hers,
you wed me to her hand, he hath her heart.
O what a wrong in you, were this to her,
being your child, and hope of after joy,
O what a wrong in me, were this to him,
being my friend, my dear, esteemed friend,
to rob her of her hearts best happiness,
him of the good his gracious fortune gives:
If I should hinder him, or you keep her,
from this right match, which reason doth prefer.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Bones a dod Nell, how? love master Stuklie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A handsome proper man, but how now daughter? must maids be choosers.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Madam and kind Sir Thomas, look on me,
not with disdainful looks, or base contempt.
I am a Gentleman, and well derived,
equal I may say, in all true respects,
with higher fortune than I aim at now.
But since your daughters virtues and firm love,
in each of us hath made resolved choice,
Since my dear friend to me hath yielded up,
what right he might prefer to your fair child,
in true regard of our so mutual love:
So you yourselves make perfect those fair hopes,
that by contracted marriage you expect,
where either party resteth fully pleased.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Upon my knees dear parents I entreat it,
and count it not in me immodesty,
to love the man, whom heaven appointed for me.
your choice I must commend, but mine much more,
bearing the seal of firm affection,
his virtues in the public worlds repute,
deserveth one more worthy than myself,
Since master Vernon then prefers his friend,
before himself, and in so just a case:
let me entreat that reason may take place.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: To further it, thus frankly I begin,
here dear Tom stukly, all the right I have,
In fair Nell Curtes, I resign to thee.
be but her parents, pleased so well as I,
God give you joy as man, and wife say I.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: What says Sir Thomas shall I call him father? and Madam, you my mother?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Soft and fair Sir.
Come hither wife, stukly is a gallant man,
and one here in our City much beloved,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Nay husband, both in Court and country too,
a Gentleman well born, and as I hear,
his fathers heir, the match were not amiss
since Nell is so affected to him, and beside,
you see that master Vernon leaves her quite,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Passion of me wife, but I heard last day,
he is very wild, a quarreller, a fighter,
Aye, and I doubt a spend good too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That is but youthfulness, marriage will tame him,
young Gentlemen will run their course awhile,
and yet be never the worse.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Say ye so wife,
Well, Son Vernon (should have been) and master Stukley.
Come, we will dine together, and talk more
concerning this new motion. Well Nell, well,
you cannot choose a man? not you? by yea and nay,
I grow in good opinion of him, come, no more ado,
we will to dinner, and be merry too.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: I feel thee coming fortune, if it prove,
blessed be the wooing speeds so soon of love.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter maister stukly, and maister Newton, a sittisen.

sp.speaker: Old Stuklie.
sp.p: By our Lady we have sitten well my host it is one a clock my watch says: what says your clock

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.p: much there about Sir, is it your pleasure we prepare your Lodging.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: What else Sir, nay I will not change mine host
good master Newton I will be bold with you
mine old friend and acquaintance and companion,
whoever else be here I must be one,
you shall not drive me from you: that you shall not.

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.l: my very worshipful and loving friend master
stukly you are right welcome to my house,
and be as bold hear as you were at home
will you abroad so soon Sir after Dinner.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: Yes Sir about a little Businesses:

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.l: Beshrew me Sir, you have come far today
I pray you rest yourself this after noon,
your Bed shall be made ready if you please,
and take tomorrow for your Businesses.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: O Sir I thank you, but it shall not need,
I thank god Sir I am as fresh and lusty
as when I set this morning from mine Inn,
tut forty miles it is nothing before noon:
now in mid April and the way is so fair.

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.l: I am younger than yourself by twenty years,
and By our Lady would not under take it.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: Ho twenty years ago: I have ridden from this
Town to my house and never draw bit:
but master Newton those days and I be parted
well Sir I will to the Temple to see my son,
when saw you that unthrifty Boy Tom Stuklie

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.l: He was not here since you were last in town
but the other day I saw him come up fleet-street
with the Lord Winsor, and Lord Aburganny,
an Irish Lord or two in company,
I promise you he is a gallant man:

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: I had as live you had seen him in the Temple
walk, conferring with some learned Councellor
or at the moot upon a case in Law.

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.l: Sir so you may I doubt not on occasion

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: I promise you I doubt it master Newton,
I hear some things that pleaseth me but a little,
it is not my allowance serves the turn
to maintain company with Noblemen.

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.l: Why Sir it shows he Bears a gallant mind
In faith he is a gallant sprightly youth,
of a fine mettle and an Active spirit,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: god make him honest Sir: and give him grace

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.l: my wife expects your company at supper,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: Yes Sir God willing.

sp.speaker: Newton.
sp.l: and if your son be at leisure, I pray you bring him

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, I hear his courage very much commended
but to licentions that is all I fear,
but that he doth accommodate with the Best,
in that he shows himself a Gentleman,
and though perhaps he shall not know so much,
I do not much mislike that humour in him.
A Gentleman of Blood and quality,
to sort himself amongst the noblest spirits,
shows the true sparks of honourable worth,
and rightly shows in this he is mine own,
For when I was of young Tom Stuklies years
and of the Inns of court as he is now,
I would be conversant still with the Best
the Bravest spirits, that were about the town,
But soft this is his chamber as I take it.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: who calls there,
gods me my masters father, now my master he is
at the Tabling house too, what the devil makes this
old Crackle-breech here now, howe the pox
stumbled he hither, god save your worship.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: how now Boy? where is your master

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: he is not come from dinner Sir,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: how not from dinner: it is past dinner time in
the hall an hour ago. Hark ye sirrah tell me
true is he in commands, tell me not a lie now

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: What shall I do, I am in a pitiful case A pox on
him for an old Scant-pouch: if he take me with a
lie now, by this flesh and blood, he will whip me
most Perniciously: if I should say he is in commands
and he prove it not so, by this light he will pepper me,
faith I will tell truth.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: Sirrah why speak you not,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I think he be not in commands Sir,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: Where dines he,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: At Palmers ordinary,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: your master is an ordinary Student,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: indeed Sir he studies very extraordinarily,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: and you the rope-ripe ordinarily,
I sent him money to provide him Books

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: See see, the devil ought my master a shame and
now he has paid him: he had never so much grace as
to Buy him a key to his study door: if he have
ere a Book there, but old hacked swords as Foxes
Bilboes, and Horne-Buckles, I am an Infidel, I
cannot tell what to do. I will devise some scuse

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: Sirrah hear ye me, give me the key of his study

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir he ever carries it about him,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: how let me see methinks the door stands open

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: A plague on it, he hath found it: I was not war
Sir, be like he had thought he had lock it and turned
the key too short.
now we shall see this old cutter play his part
for in faith he is furnished with all kind of weapons,

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: what be these my sons books I promise you A
study richly furnished. well said Tom stukly,
Here gallows clapper here. Be these your masters Books?
for Littleton, stamford and Brooke here is
long sword, short sword, and Buckler, but all is
for the Bar: yet I had meant to have made my
son a Barrister not a Baratter: but I see he
means not to trouble the law: I pray god the law
trouble not him: sirrah Halter-sack

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.p: Where is this towardly youth your master. this Lawyer this Lawyer, I would fain see him, his learned mastership: where is he.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: It will not be long before he comes Sir.

body.stage: Old Sukly goes againe to the studdy.

sp.l: If he be not cursed in his mothers Belly
he will keep him out of the way: I would I were with
him too: for I shall have a Baiting worse than a hanging

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.p: If he have so much as a candlestick I am a traitor, but an old hilt of a Broken sword to set his light in
sp.l: not a standeth as I am a man, but the Bottom
of a Temple pot, with a little old sarsenet in it.
here is a fellow like to prove a Lawyer, if sword and,
Buckler hold.

body.stage: Enter stuklie at the further end of the stage.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Boy, has Dicke Blackstone sent home my new Buckler, rogue why stirs thou not

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: What a gaping keep you: a pox on it, my old master is hear: you will hate i'faith.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: How long has he been here rogue.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: This two hours.

sp.speaker: stukly.
sp.p: Zounds he has been taking an Inventory of my household stuff: all my bravery lies about the flour

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: O thou graceless boy, how dost thou bestow thy time

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Your blessing good father.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: O thou unblessed Boy, thou vild lewd unthrift

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: How does my mother Sir, and all in Hampshire,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: The worse to hear of thy demeanour here

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: I am glad to hear of their good health: god continue it.

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: Thou graceless rake hell and is all my cost
this five years space here for thy maintenance,
spent in this sort thou lewd misordered villain.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Sir I am glad to see you look so well,
I promise you it Joys me at the heart
boy bring the chair and let my father sit,
and if old master Prouye be within
I will call him sir to bear you company

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: Aye, aye, thou carest not how thou stoppest my mouth
so that thou hearst not of thy Villainy,
it is no marvel though you write so oft
for several sums to furnish you with Books,
believe me Sir, your study is richly furnished:

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: This villain boy, never Dresses up the chamber
I pray thee put these things out of the way.

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: I would I could cast thee out of the way
And so I should not see my shameless son
Be these the Books Sir that you look upon.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Father this as right a Fox as ere you saw
And has been as soundly tried as any blade in England

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.p: I trust you will make me account Sir of my money.
Indeed Sir: he does rescind very fast in the hilts, And is a little Crooked at the point:

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: Tom Stukly, what a shame is this for thee,
To see so many of thy countrymen
Of whom the world did never expect thy hopes
so forward, and so towardly to the Law,
And thou whose infancies did flatter me,
with expectation of so many goods:
To prove A very changeling and to follow,
these ruffianly and vild disordered courses.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.p: Nay hark you father I pray you be content. I have done my goodwill, but it will not do. Iohn A-Nokes and Iohn A-styles and I cannot cotton. O this law french is worse than Buttered mackerel, full of Bones, full of Bones, it sticks here it will not down, Aurum potabile will not get it down, my grand-father, bestowed as much of you as you have Done of me, but of my conscience you were as I am, a true man to the house, you took nothing away with you.

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: O had thy grandsire been as kind to me
as I have been to thee, thou vild lewd unthrift
I had done well.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: nay so you do, God be thanked, but hark you
Father there is a nearer way to the wood than all
This. A nearer cut, than scratching for things out
Of a standish all a man's life, which I have found
Out, and if you will stick to me, I doubt not but
You shall think I have bestowed my time well
And this it is. I am in possibility to marry Alderman
Curtesses Daughter, now father if you will
Open the Bag of your affection and speak but
A few good words for me to the old Alderman
she is mine horse and foot.

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: But with what colour can I speak for thee
Being so lewd and Prodigal a (spend thrift)
A common quarreller, with shame I speak it,
That I dare scarcely own thee with my credit.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Peace good father: no more of that, stick to me
once, if you will but tickle the old fellow in
The ear, look you, with a certain word called a Jointer:
Ha, that same Jointer, and a proper man withal
as I am, will draw you on a wench: as a
squirrels skin, will draw one a spanish shoe

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: Now aforegod Tom stukly: thy riots
Are so notorious in the City:
As I am much afraid the Alderman,
Will not be wrought to yield unto the match,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Aye father this is certain, but all that is nothing,
I have the wenches goodwill and he must yield
Spite of his heart: she is worth forty thousand pound
O father this is the right Philosophers
stone, true multiplication I have found it.

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: Well Sirrah, come and go with me to supper:
whether I will send for a friend or two of mine,
and take their Better counsels in the matter.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: I pray you let it be so: Sirrah Boy
Lock the door, and bring my sword:

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I will Sir.

body.stage: Enter at one doore Crosse the Mercer at another spring the Vintyner.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: I never heard such a murmur of a marriage
Yet for my life I cannot meet a man
that soundly can report the certainty,

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: I cannot meet a man in any place,
But still he hath this marriage in his mouth,
This day says one, tomorrow says another
Another says it is past, and he was there:
Another tells me that upon his knowledge
it is not yet this three dais at the least:
I think the world is set a madding I.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: What master spring the Vintner
I pray god Sir your smell be as good as your taste

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: Master Cross the Mercer is it even so, you have
something in the wind: I believe you have been brought to
the Book as well as your neighbours: upon my life he
Comes upon the same Business that I do, and perhaps
he can tell me how the world goes here
well met master Cross.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: What master spring whether away:

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: I was about to ask you as much
Come, I know you are harkening to Alderman Curt. hear

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.p: O you would fain have some company, I feel you. Go to, Tom Stukely shall have the wench: and helter skelter, the Alderman's bags shall pay for all.

sp.speaker: spring
sp.l: Art thou a true Prophet?

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.p: I was adreamt tonight, that he paid me all in double Pistolets.

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: I would I had mine in plain Testerns.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: Tut, beggarly payment, hang it.

body.stage: Enter sharpe the Cutlar, and Blunt the Buckler maker.

sp.p: What, more of the same Covey, all birds of a feather

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: Sharpe the Cutler of Fleetstreat methinks,
And Blunt of the Strand the Buckler maker.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.p: Have at him at Blunt and Sharpe, for sword and buckler, we are for him.

sp.speaker: sharp.
sp.l: Well met master Spring.

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: So are you master Sharpe.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: What master Blunt, shall we lie at Ward?

sp.speaker: Blunt
sp.p: I pray God we may sir, to save ourselves by this marriage.

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: Stay here comes Tom.
Stukely, and Iacke Harbart.

body.stage: Enter Stukely and Harbart in their hose and doublets.

sp.speaker: Crosse
sp.l: What is the matter.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: To speak it publicly, in such a presence,
he hath undone his daughter by the marriage,
you are a most disgraceful Idiot:
The greatest injury ere crossed my spirit
could not have drawn so base a wrong from me.

sp.speaker: Harbart
sp.l: I spake it but in mirth, but since your snuff
Is so soon lighted, let it quench again:
Are you so tetche Stukely, with a pox.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: You are a slave thus to abuse me Harbert,

sp.speaker: Harb
sp.l: you are a vain fool Stukely so to call me,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Enforce me not I prithee at this time.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Enforce you, 'sblood, you will not be enforced

sp.speaker: stuke.
sp.l: Harbart your blood is too hot

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: You have brought me into the air to cool it then.

sp.speaker: stuke.
sp.l: Thou hast almost tempted me beyond my strength

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: if I wished that I would be your evil spirit.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: here is sword and buckler by me call for clubs.

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: so we may beat out the Brains of our business,

sp.speaker: sharp.
sp.l: we come in an ill time.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: So I fear.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: how now Sharp, is your edge taken off.

sp.speaker: sharp.
sp.l: I am blunted with my neighbour in faith.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Thou camest on purpose Harbert to disgrace me.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Sirrah your mothers son lies in his throat.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: I pray thee stand not thus.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: To under prop your choler lest it fall.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Thou hast found a time to triumph one my courage when I am gived: durst thou else have said thus much.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: When will ye be unfettered.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Wherever I meet you next, I will have you by the ears

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.p: Stukly you shall not I will keep you from my ears by the length of my rapier.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: say no more.

body.stage: Enter Curteis, Mother Bride, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Where is my husband, where is master stuklie, alas my heart: upon my wedding to fall on it thus.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: For gods love: good son stuklie and M. Harbart pacify yourself.

sp.speaker: Curtisse.
sp.p: Fie, Tom fie, fie, Bones a Dod man, what coil is here

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: What mean you sir: why rise you from the table we rise for nothing but to talk a little,
Harbart look to it, by this Blessed day I will be with you

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: I would the day were come,
but you take day still with your creditors.

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: I do not like that,

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: What doest thou mean.

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: That he should take longer day with his creditors.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: For gods love good son Stukely be content.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: gods blessed Captain Harbert, Bones of Dod man be content.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: we are good friends with all my heart,
the Dining room Sir growing somewhat hot,
we stepped out hither but to take the air,

sp.speaker: Stuke.
sp.l: Bride.
I pray thee good sweet heart be not so angry,
and Captain Harbart let me tell you this,
knowing the disposition of your friend,
you might have spared the speeches that you used.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: If they have any way displeased you,
I am very sorry.
But let him take them how he will I care not,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Harbart, I will make you eat your words.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Gods me blessed, let us to dinner again, all is, well all is well, Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.p: Come Master Harb. you shall be my prisoner: Daughter take you your husband by the hand, and let us in to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.p: Here is a wedding indeed. I perceive by this, that we come in ill season for our money.

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.p: I would I had my debt before Harbart and he meet

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.l: why so master spring?

sp.speaker: spring.
sp.l: Because, If they two meet, I fear
One of them pays for it, they are two tall
Gentlemen, as England yields.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Well, let us away for this, and come tomorrow the sooner.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: Content.

body.stage: Enter Vernon with Hamdon and Ridley, two of his Friends.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: If not at our requests, yet gentle friend,
For your own safety, change your former mind:
Have you not wealth, Why should you leave the Land?

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Are you not here of credit in the City,
Why should you then betray your forward hopes
Upon a wilful and uncertain humour?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I know that my estate is sound and good,
as on the one side strengthened with rich friends,
and one the other well established
by the assistance of a private stock:
yet what is this? Or all external pomp
that otherwise is incident to men,
If the mind want that comfort it should have?
believe me Gentlemen it is as music,
to men in prison, or as Dainty meat
brought to a sick man, whose afflicting pain
hath neither left him appetite nor taste.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How springs this discontent? wherein lies
this gall of Conscience that disturbs you so?

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: We are your friends show us your inward grief,
And we will either find a remedy,
Or sharing every one a part of it.
So lessen it, and it shall lose his force.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: In it for sorrow you forsook your Bride,
and gave your interest to another man.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: You hit the nail upon the head: it is that
and nothing else that breeds this discontent.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Be not deceived, I did it by advise,
Nor do I any way repent me of it:
She loved not me, albeit I honoured her:
and such a match what were it but to join
fire and water? Marriage is no toy,
to be desired where there is Dislike,
and therefore weighing his deserts with mine,
her love to him, and his to her again,
I rather chose to benefit my Friend,
whereby two might be pleased: than greedily
assuming what I might, displease all three.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What then hath weaned you from your country's love?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Nor that, nor anything, I know not what:
yet whilst I breath this native air of mine,
Methinks I suck in poison to my heart:
and whilst I tread upon this English earth,
It is as if I set my careless feet
Upon a bank, where underneath is hid
a bed of crawling Serpents: any place
but only here (methinks) would make me happy,
Say it were the meanest Cottage in the world:
But here I am accursed, and here I live.
as one deprived both of soul and sense.
Which strange conceit from whence it should proceed,
I cannot utter, other than from this,
That I am fired with a desire to travel,
and see the fashions, state, and qualities
of other Countries: Therefore if you love me
offer no further to resist in me
The settled resolution of my mind.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Yet since you needs will leave us and the Realm,
go not to Ireland: The countries rude
and full of tumult and rebellious strife,
Rather make choice of Italy or France.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My word is past unto a Gentleman,
with whom I will not break: and here he comes.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Sir as I told you, even at dinner time,
His fury was so great, as he must needs
Rise from the table to confer with me,
About my speeches which I did maintain,
And sure if place had served we there had fought,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I would I could devise to make you friends.
The rather for I hear he is appointed.
to have a charge in this our Irish expedition.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is no matter: Harbart fears him not,
I make as little reckoning of my blood
as he of his: and will at any time,
Or when he dares meet him upon that quarrel.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Captain well met.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Master Uernon we stay for you,
Our horses half an hover ago were ready,
And we had backed them but we lacked your company.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Some conference with these gentlemen my friends
Made me neglect mine hour: but when you please,
I now am ready to attend on you.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: It is well done, we will away forthwith,
Saint albans though the day were further spent
We may well reach to bed tonight.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Kind friends I now must bid ye both farewell.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay we will see you Mounted ere we part.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Sirrah, what men are those that stay without?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Some that would speak with M. Stukly Sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Knowest what their business is, or whence they come

sp.speaker: Cash:
sp.l: Tradesmen they are, and of the City sir,
But what their business is I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Upon my life some Creditors of his,
That hearing of his matching with my Daughter
come to demand some money which he owes them.
It is even so, They know he hath received
his marriage money: they perceive he is flush,
and mean to share with him, ere all be gone.
I will see the sequel: Here he comes himself,
and with him (O the body of me)
Half the Tradesmen in the town (I think)

body.stage:
Enter Stukelie with bagges of money. After him thronging Arthur Crosse the Mercer, Iohn sparing the Vint. William sharp, Tho, Thump, Geo, haz, tennis keeper, henry Crackc
The Fencer, and Ieffery Blurt, Bailiff of Finsbury: with written notes in their hands.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Now ye slaves: a man can no sooner step
into a little wealth, but presently
you will have the sent of him, you will visit him,
here is bills enough: had I now as many
shot and picks, I would with a valiant band
of mine own subjects march among the Irish,
but let me see: deliver your petition
I will prove an honest man at the chancery

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Little law I fear and lesser Conscience.

sp.speaker: stukly
sp.l: The gross sum of your debt Sir.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.l: For silks and velvets Sir.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Your name.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Arthur Cross the Mercer.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Well master Cross, the first syllable of your name might have spared ye this labour: but all is one: there is your money.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Two hundred pounds? so there is an end of that, I will be sworn I got it not so soon.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Your title to my purse.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Thirty pounds Sir.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: For Tavern suppers, and for quarts of wine

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: O at the Gray hound in fleetstreet.

sp.speaker: spa.
sp.l: Aye Sir the same.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Your name is Sparing.

sp.speaker: spa.
sp.l: Iohn Sparing Sir, the vintner.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: you spared not him when you did score so much:

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: There master Sparing, would I were your scholar
That I might learn to spare as well as you,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: That will near be until it be too late.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Now Sir to you.

sp.speaker: sharp.
sp.p: Your servant Sir: william Sharp for Bilboes, Foxes and Tolledo blades.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: What.

sp.speaker: sharp.
sp.l: Forty marks:

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: you cut somewhat deep master Sharp, but there is a preservative for a green wound.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Beshrew me but it wounds me: what preservative have I for that.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Of whence are you,

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Thomas Thumpe Sir, the Buckler maker of Saint Giles

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: The sum thereunto belonging.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Fifteen pound Sir for broad and Bucklers beside steel picks,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Body of me, half the money would arm five tall fellows for the wars.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Thumpe I will not answer you with the like violence for if I should, the broadest buckler that ever you made would not defend you from being bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Are you sick of the yellows too?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Not so sick Sir but I hope to have a child's part by your last will and testament

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: There is a knave, he thinks after they are paid? he means to go and hang himself: what is his legacy

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: For tennis Balls when the French ambassador was here thirteen pound: is it so much.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Just so much with the fowling of fair Linen when you were hot.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Fair Linen? hoy day: your fair Linen wipes him of a good deal of money.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Georg Hazzard I take it that is your name.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: my name is so Sir.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: George: you have hit the hazzard,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It was a hazzard whether he would have hit or no, But for my money.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: What else.

sp.speaker: Crack.
sp.l: I hope Sir: your worship hath not forgot Harry
Crack the Fencer, for forfeits, and vennyes given upon a
wager at the ninth button of your doublet, thirty Crowns.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Crack his crown and that makes one and thirty.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Well Crack I have no way to defend your thrust, but by this down right blow.

sp.speaker: Crack.
sp.l: I take it double Sir, and please you

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Let it suffice your valiant and my choler past.
More clients yet? your name?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Geffery Blurt Sir. Bailiff of Finsburie For frays and bloodshed in the theatre fields, Five marks.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Body of me never a Surgeon in this town would have asked more.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Blurt I have no reason to pay thee whole.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Why so if it please you.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Iack Dudley and I were haues in that action take part of him.

sp.speaker: Blur.
sp.p: Alas Sir, he is in Finsbury Jail for hurting a man behind the windmills last Saturday.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.p: Why then belike you have good pawn for your money

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: I would we had Sir.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.p: Well I see your Dogged natures: a good sword and buckler man is of no reckoning amongst ye: but let the Sheriff think, when he hath lost Iack Dudly, he loseth twenty mark a year as good fee simple as ever a baron in England holds. There is your amerciaments. And give Iack Dudley this from me to pay his Fees.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: I thank ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I would he had broke his pate ere he went in earnest,
of a new reckoning: ah son, son, thou hast deceived
my opinion, my daughter cast away, and I have
bequeath my money to a prodigal.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Father why so, shall I not pay my debts?

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Not with my money son, not with my money.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: It is mine own, and Stuklie of his own,
will be as Frank as shall the Emperor.
I scorn this trash, betrayer of men's souls:
I will spurn it with my foot: and with my hand,
Reign showers of plenty one this Barren land,
were it my fortune could exceed the clouds,
yet would I bear a mind surmounting that.
father you have enough for your, and for your store
When mine is gone you must provide me more.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Is it even so. The captains words are true:
he is a spend thrift but I will keep him short
he gets not a denier more than he hath.

body.stage: Enter Lady Curteis and Old Stuklie.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Husband you are sent for in all the haste
to the yield hall, about the Soldiers
that are to be dispatched for Ireland.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I may be sent for wife whether I will,
and it is no matter greatly where I go,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why so I pray.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Would you ere have thought
that taverns, Fencers, Bailiffs, and such like,
should by the fruits of my late sitting up,
and early rising, have maintained their state,

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: What mean ye brother Curteis.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Ah brother Stuklie,
My meaning had you been but here even now,
you might have scanned without my utterance,
here was Item, upon Item, such a crew
as I never saw one man indebted too.

body.stage: Enter Stukely, Lieft, Ens, Drum, and soldiors.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: Here stay we soldiers till the hour be come
our captain did appoint to meet with us:
The valiant Stukly: we shall have a guide,
There is not a better in the Regiment.
It is not one will say unto his men
Give you assault upon, the enemy
follow me: and so himself will be
The foremost man that shall begin the fight.
Nor will he nicely creep into the the town,
when we are lodged within the dampish field,
but voluntarily partake your toil,
and of his private purse relieve your wants,

sp.speaker: Ens.
sp.l: Lieutenant he is a gallant Gentleman.
We know it well, and he that is not willing
to venture life with him, I would for my part
he might end his days worser than the pestilence.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: Nay if you look but on his mind,
much more occasion shall ye find to love him
He is liberal, and goes not to the wars
to make a gain of his poor Soldiers spoil,
but spoil the foe to make his Soldiers gain,
and here he comes stand all in good array.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: I prithee wife Importune me no more,
might tears persuade or words prevail with me,
thy tears and words ere this had won me state:
but it is not thou nor any power but his
that has that power to take away my life,
that can abridge my purpose I will go.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: shall then my joys have an end ere they begin
and shall the term of three days being Wife,
for ever after cause a widowhood,
We scarce are joined together and must part,
we scarce are warm within our nuptial bed,
and you forsake me there to freeze alone:
O do not so and if you ever loved,
or if you never loved, yet in regard
of my affection, leave me not so soon

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Good Lord that thou wilt still importune me,
Have I not said I undertake this task,
Only to make thee great.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But I desire to be no more than what I am already
So by your absence I be made no less.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: But that contents not me, it is not chambering
Now I have beauty to be dallying with,
Nor pampering of myself with belly cheer,
Now I have got a little worldly pelf,
that is the end or levels of my thought:
I must have honour, honour is the thing
Stukly doth thirst for, and to clime the Mount
Where she is seated gold shall be my footstool,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But there are many dangers by the way,
and hasty climbers quickly catch a fall.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: he soonest loseth that despairs to win,
but I have no such prejudicial fear,
If there be any shall outlive the brunt
of raging war, or purchase dignity,
I am persuaded to be one of those.
If all miscarry: yet it will not grieve,
or grieve the less to die with company.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That name of death already martyrs me,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Tut never fear: and if I chance to die
Thou being a lusty widow: there is enough
will gladly sue to be received of thee,
the worst is I confess, I leave thee poor,
as taking with me all the Jewels thou hast,
And all the coin was given me for thy dower:
But I do leave thee with a wealthy father,
And one that will not see thee want I know,
Beside thou hast a jointure of such Lands,
as I am born unto: and therefore seize,
And let me seal thy lips up with this kiss.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Stay but a day or two and then depart.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: are not my soldiers ready: what a shame
were it to send them forward and myself
come lagging after like one that fears,
or went unwillingly unto wars,
as thou respects me talk no more to me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Am I so odious that I may not speak,
Well I have listened when you talked ere now,
Or words had been the harvest of your hope,
But since to silence I am so enjoined,
I would my life might likewise have an end

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: March hence away, or still there will be cast,
Some let or other to detract our haste.

body.stage: As they are Marching, Enter curteis and Old Stukly.

sp.speaker: cur.
sp.l: Bones a Dod man, lay down thy tabor sticks,
And hear me speak, or with my Dudgeon dagger
I will play a fit of mirth upon thy pate.
Why hear me Tom, hear me son stukly, ha:
What here today, and gone tomorrow. See
Thy wife laments, canst thou behold her weep,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Sound drums I say: I will not hear a word.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: Wilt thou not hear thy father Graceless Boy.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Father, unless you mean I shall be thought
a traitor to her Majesty: a coward,
a sleepy dormouse, and a carpet squire
Mix not my forward summer with sharpe breath,
Nor intercept my purpose being good.

sp.speaker: Old Stuk.
sp.l: I come not wilful Boy as a reprover
Of any virtuous action thou intends,
But to reprove thy lack of husbandry,
And the unthrifty courses thou hast used,
Learn to be sober, and not rashly thus,
To rush into affairs of such great moment.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Father, I know not what you term rashness,
But any time since I was of the skill
Or strength to wield a sword, I vowed in heart
To be a soldier, and the time now serves,
And now my vow shall be accomplished,
For anything betwixt my wife and me:
we are agreed: how ever sower cheer
Do at our parting show the contrary:
If you as well as she can be persuaded,
Why so, if not sound drums I will not hear no more.

sp.speaker: cur.
sp.l: Nay Tom, son Tom, thou art deceived in me
I am not grieved that thou shouldst serve thy prince,
Nor do I take exceptions at thy mind,
So long as honour is thy object Tom,
But that without our knowledge thou departs,
And one the sudden: body of me, it is that
That strikes a discontentment in us all.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: I cannot help it Sir, with all my heart,
And in all reverend duty of a Son,
I take my farewell: Fathers of you both
Thus much entreating if I never return,
Ye would have both a care unto my wife.

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: Well Brother Curtise hope the best of him
He may return a comfort to us all,
And were he not my son I would commend
His resolution, it is heroical.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: There is no remedy now but patience,
But were the Bargain to be begin again,
I would be twice advised ere I would bestow
My daughter so: ywis, so large a sum,
Is more than I had thought should fly with wings,
Of vain expenses into Ireland.
But all is one, come daughter never mourn,
I will not see thee want whilst I do live.

sp.speaker: Old stuk.
sp.l: I hope she hath the like conceit of me,
Then comfort girl fear no extremity.

body.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Oneale O Hamlon and Neale Makener.

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.l: O Hamlon.

sp.speaker: Hamlon.
sp.l: Ow.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Tread softly on the stones,
The water tells us we are near the town,
Neale Mackener come on, fix all our eyes
upon the walls of this bewitched town,
that harbours such a sort of English churls,
to see if any signal be set out
Where we shall enter to surprise Dundalke.

sp.speaker: Mackener.
sp.l: Oneale speak softly we are near the walls,
the English Sentinels do keep good watch,
if they descry us all our labours lost.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Our labour lost, for we can see no sign
of any white that hangeth over the wall.
Where we shall enter by our spies within.

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.l: A plague upon the drowsy drunken slaves,
Bryan Mac Phelim, and that Neale O Quyme,
Who being Drunk or sleeping with his Drabs,
Forget the business that they have in hand.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: O Neale be patient and suspect the worst,
they may unto the English be betrayed,
or else perceiving strong watch every where,
Dare not approach the walls or gates for fear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Oneale, thy secretary says very true,
the English knowing all the power so never,
will be more watchful than their custom is,
So both our spies and friends dare not assay,
To hang out signal nor come never the Port.

sp.speaker: Neale.
sp.l: Why so it is, I know within Dundalke.
I have ten friends to one the English have.
I mean of towns men: but sure policy
Cannot by might attain our entrance in.
that we might cut of all the English heads,
Of theirs that watch and theirs that sleep in beds
let us withdraw unto our troupes again,
tomorrow comes O Kane with Gallinglasse,
and teage magennies, with his light-foot kern,
then will we not come mitching thus by night,
But charge the town and win it by day light,
O Hanlon, captain Harbart shall be thine,
and Gainsfords ransom shall be Mackeners.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Thanks great Oneale.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: Be whist I hear one stir

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.l: Some English Soldier that hath got the cough,
I will ease that grief by cutting off his head.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: These English churls die if they lack their bed,
and bread and beer porridge and powdered beef.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: O Marafastot shamrocks, are no meat,
Nor Bonny clabbo, nor green Water-cresses,
Nor our strong butter, nor our swelled oatmeal,
and drinking water brings them to the Flixe.

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.l: It is there niceness silly pulling fools,

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: There be of them can fare as hard as we,
and harder too, but drunkards and such like.
as spend their time in ale house surfeiting,
And brothel houses quickly catch their Bane,

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.l: One coughs again, let us slip aside unseen,
tomorrow we will ease them of their spleen.

body.stage: Enter Shane Oneale O Hanlon, Neale Mackener softly as by night.

sp.speaker: Onele.
sp.l: O Hanlon.

sp.speaker: Humlon.
sp.l: Owe.

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.p: Fate is the token? fate siegne that Brian Mack Phelem said he would hang out?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: I feate I know not ask the Secretary.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Neale Mackener.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Hest, Oneale hest, pease too art at the water seed.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p:
Fate is the token bodeaugh breene? That I shall see
Over the vales of this Town of Dundalke.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: I feat Oneale thou art Saint Patrick his cushin and a great Lord, but thou art not wise. The siegne is a pair Of feet trousers, or a feet shirt, or some feet blanked, To be hang out over the vales, fan we shall be let in At the little Booygh door by the abbey.

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.p: Esta clamper, thou talkest too much the English Upon the wall will hear the, lake, faugh bodeaugh Dost thou see anything feat.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: No by this hand, shan Oneal, we see no feat thing

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Cresh bless us, fo ish tat ishe coughs.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Saint Patrick bless us we be not betrayed.

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.p: Mackener, Mack Deawle, marafastot art thou a feat livered kana: It is some English churl in the town That coughs, that is three, some proud English soldier he is a three cough, can drink no water. The English churl does If he get not bread and porridge and a hose to lee in: but look is the signe, out, zeele cut his throat and Help him of his cough fan I get into Dundalk.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Be this hand Oneale there is no siegne, zee am afraid Brian Mack Phelemy is with his streepo, and forgets To hang a siegne or let us in.

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.p: No matter come, no noise it is almost day, softly let us creep about by the vales seed ane awan soon at night Even at shutting of the gates fan Ocane and Magennis Come from Carlingford, we will Enter lustily the town Mackener O Hanlon, zee will give you tree captains to ransom.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Zee will take tree prisoners and give thee too and take the turd myself

sp.speaker: One.
sp.p: Speak softly O Hanlon and you make ready for kern and Gallinglasse against night, and bid my bagpiper be ready to peep Ballootherie soon, for I will sleep in Dundalke at night. come go back into the Fewes again.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Slave haggat Bryan Mac Phelemy.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.p: Slave let us Rorie beg.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Herbart at one dore with soldiors, and Vernon at another.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: God morrow master Vernon.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: God morrow Captain Harbart.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Is it your use to be so early up
such vigilance doth fit us soldiers best,
and search our garrisons for fear of spies,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And travellers that use to walk the round,
of every Country to survey the world,
must not be friend with sleep and idleness.
But in plain terms I do prevent mine hour,
by reason of a gentle man's report
that is a soldier and did walk the round,
Who coming in this morning to his rest,
said the enemy was about the town tonight.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: So said this soldier that stood Sentinel,
now this last watch at Dawning of the day,
that he did hear hard by the water side,
never the North gate that opens toward the Fewes,
some trampling on the gravel up and down:
he did but Cough and thought to call to them,
And they were gon: soldier was it so.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Yes governor I know it was Shane Oneale,
they were so whist whilst they were never the walls,
pray god the have no spies within the town.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Thou prayest too late, the townsmen are spies,
and help and store them with provision,
and love them better than us Englishmen.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: It behooves you therefore to be circumspect

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Fear not you that, I will search the town myself,
and place a double guard at every gate.
How stands the wind?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: From England very fair.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: We look for fresh supplies to come from thence
to strength our garrison for it is but weak,
and we must bear the brunt of all the North.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: your men are healthful.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: there is no soldier sick,
But he that drinks or spend his thrift at dice

body.stage: Sound a Drume a sare of,

sp.l: what drum is this?

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: A drum without the town.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Some band of men from England new arrived,
or else some Company of the English Pale,
bid Captain Gainsford guard the Southern Port:
Toward Tredaghe, and take that Company in,
I will see our troops in readiness this day,
for I expect the Irish soune at night,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What will you do.
I will to the southern Port,
to see what Captain leads this band of men

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: I make ye lieutenant Governor for the time.

body.stage: Enter Stukely, his Lifetenant Auntient Drume Souldiers and Company.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: I muse what Lord is governor of this town,
That comes not forth to welcome Stukely in.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: The towns so long he cannot hear our Drum,
And if he did he knows not whose it is?

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Drum, thumpe thy tapskinnes hard about the pate

body.stage: Drumme sounds Enter Vernon Gainsford and Soldiers.

sp.l: and make the Ram-heads hear that are within:
Zounds who is that Vernon with a partisan,
Is he a Soldier? then the Enemy is dead.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Is Stukly come? Whom I desire to shun?
and must he needs to Ireland follow me?
I will not draw that air wherein he breaths,
one kingdom shall not hold us if I can.

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: Is not this lusty Stukly with his men?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes captain Gainsford this is lusty Tom.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: These gallants are grown ceremonies,
They stand at gaze as if they knew me not,
Or else they strain a further compliment,
to see if I will vaile my bonnet first,
I will eat my feather ere I move my hat,
Before I see their crowns uncovered.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: Cherish that humour it becomes your port.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He doth expect we should salute him first:

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: It is fit we should for he is but new arrived,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You are welcome into Ireland captain Stukly.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Gramercies master Uernon, and well met,
I did not dream that you professed arms,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: It is not my profession but my pleasure
The Governor being busy in the town,
Makes we Lieutenant Governor for the time.

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: Brave captain Stukley welcome to Dundalk.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Thanks captain Gainsford even withal my heart.

body.stage: Stuklies Lieft. deliuers a Letter to vernon.

sp.speaker: ver.
sp.l: To me Lieutenant? from whom I pray ye.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: From an old friend.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I will see what friend it is

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: What Enemy lies there never about this town?

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: The Rebel Shane Oneale and all his power.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Why do ye not beat them home into their dens?

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: We have enough a do to keep the Town.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: To keep the town? dare they beleaguer it?

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: Aye and assault it.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Hang them savage slaves,
Belike they know you dare not issue out,
Who is Governor here?

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: That is Captain Harbart Sir.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: 'sdeath I am bewitched, mine enemy Governor,
well it is no matter, I will about without him,
So soon as ere I see him by this light
It is marvel he will endure their proud approach,
Harbert is valiant: but the slaves are proud,
And have no boot to fetch worth following them.

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: Yes captain Stukly they have gallant horse,
The best in Ireland are of Ulsters breed,
They have a pray of Garrans cows and sheep,
Well worth a brace of thousand pounds at least,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Hang cows and sheep, but have among their horse,
I will lose this head but I will have hobbies from them.
What news from England that ye read so long

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The largest news concerns yourself.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Wherein.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Will Mallerye writes, ye do not love your wife,
You are unkind, you make not much of her.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Writs he I have not made much of my wife,
I will tell ye captain how much I have made,
I have made away her portion and her plate,
Her borders, bracelets, chains and all her Rings,
And all the clothes belonging to her back,
Save one poor gown, and he that can make more,
Of one poor wife let him take her for me,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Well had I known you would have made so much,
you should not have been troubled with my love.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: come, strike up drum, let us march into the town,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Well go thy ways a kingdom is too small,
For his expense that hath no&H2; mean at all,
Doubtless if ever man was misbegot,
It is this Stukly: of a boundless mind,
Undaunted spirit, and uncontrolled spleen,
Lavish as is the liquid Ocean,
That drops his crowns even as the clouds drop Rain,
Yet once I loud him better than myself,
when like myself too prodigal in love,
I gave my love to such a Prodigal,
For which I hate the climate where he lives,
as if his breath infected all the air,
And therefore Ireland now farewell to thee,
For though thy soil no venom will sustain,
There treads a monster on thy fruitful breast,
If any shipping be for Spain or France,
Aboard will I and seek some further chance.

body.stage: Enter Herbert in a shirt of male and Booted. and his Page with him.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Boy, bid the Sergeant Major shut the gates,
And see them guarded with a double ward,
That done, bid him command the companies,
To man the walls: then bid the messenger
Haste with these letters to the Deputy,
Come captain Stukly where is your company,
Draw then with speed unto the water Port.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Is there for every one a Tankard there?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: How do you mean a Tankard?

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Sir in brief,
I made a vow you know it well enough,
For your kind speeches to my wives old Dad,
Sir Thomes Curteis: that wheresoever we met
I would fight with you, therefore your tools,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What were my speeches?

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: That the old knight had cast away his Daughter
when ye perceived she was bestowed on me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I spake those words, and thou hast proud them true

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: and for those words Harbert I will fight with you

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Rash hare brained Stuklie, knowest thou what thou dost
to quarrel in a town of Garrison,
and Draw thy weapon on the Governor?

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Zounds have ye logic to defend your skin,
Lay by your tricks and take you to your tools,
think ye your Governors title is rapier proof,

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Come, come, untruss put off those coward shifts
Stukley thou knowest I am a soldier,
And hate the name of carpet coward to death,
I tell thee but the discipline of war.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Gods, you may hang us then by the law,
By law of manhood here I challenge thee,
Lay by thy terms and answer like a man.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Thou seest the public enemy is at hand,
And we shall fight about a private brawl.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Nor shall that shift Tom Harbart serve thy turn.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Then give me leave but to disarm myself,
Thou knowest I scorn to have odds of any man.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Disarm of what? of school boys haberdines
Such as they cast at points in ever street?
No arm thy legs, put splinters in thy boots,
cask on thy head, and gauntlets on thy hands,
Would thou wert armed in pistol proof complete,
And nothing bare but even thy very lips,
I hold my head I will hurt thee in thy mouth,
Lay by thy scar-crow name of Governor,
And arm thee else unto a fingers breadth.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Braving braggart since thou dost seek thy death
Look to thyself I will speed thee if I can,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Sir your teeth bleeds this picktooth is too keen,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Hark the enemies charges we must to the walls,
another time I will pick your teeth as well.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Even when ye can. I said I would hit your mouth.

body.stage: Exeunt Ambo: Alarum is sounded, diuers excurtions, Stukly persues, shane Oneale, and Neale Mackener, And after a good pretty fight his Lieftenannt and Auntient rescue Stuklie, and chace the Ireshe out. Then an excurtion berwixt Herbert and O Hanlon, and so a retreat sounded. Enter Harbart, Gainsford, and some souldiors on the walles.

sp.speaker: har.
sp.l: Are all the gates and Posterns closed again.

sp.speaker: Gai.
sp.l: Aye every one, and strong guards at them all.

sp.speaker: har.
sp.l: Who would have thought these naked savages,
These Northern Irish durst have been so bold,
To have given assault unto a warlike town?

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: Our sufferance and remissness gives them heart,
we make them proud by mewing up ourselves,
In walled towns, whilst they triumph abroad
and Revel in the country as they please.

sp.speaker: harb.
sp.l: Well Sergeant Major we will stir abroad,
This sudden sally was performed as men,
It cut three hundred rebels throats at least,
And did discomfit and disperse them all.

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: Had we pursued we had taken a lusty pray.

sp.speaker: hatb.
sp.l: Ye see it is night, and time we should retire,
To guard the town, but hark what drum is this:
Are any of our company without?

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: It is lusty Stukley if any be abroad,
He is so eager to pursue the foe,
And flesh his soldiers that are new arrived,
that he forgot or heard not the retreat,
At which gate shall he enter Governor?

sp.speaker: harb.
sp.l: He shall not enter, give me all the keys,
I will teach him duty and true discipline

body.stage: Enter Stukly Lieftenant: Auncient Drum and soldiers, a noies within of driuing beasts.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Are the gates shut already? open how.

sp.speaker: herb.
sp.l: Who knocks so boldly?

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Ha? who is that above?

sp.speaker: her,
sp.l: Herbart the Governor, who is that below?

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Stuley the captain, knocks to be let in

sp.speaker: herb.
sp.l: Stukley the captain comes not in tonight.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: How? not tonight? I am sure ye do but jest.

sp.speaker: herb.
sp.l: I do not use to jest in these affairs.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Ye do not jest and I must stay without,
I trust you will let my company come in in.
Nor company, nor Captain comes in here,
until the morning that the gates be ope.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: We humble thank ye honourable Sir?
what if the Irish should make head, again,
and set upon us would ye rescue us,

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: No why retired ye not at the retreat,
As did myself and all the other troupes,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Because I meant not to come empty home,
But bring some booty to enrich my men,
Besides in prosecution we have slain
Two hundredth Irish since you left the chase,
And brought a prey six hundredth cows at least
Forty chief horse, a hundred hackneys Jades
and yet the Governor will not let us in.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: No sir I will not and will answer it.
If all your throats be cut you are well served,
To teach ye know the discipline of war.
There is a time to fight a time to cease,
a time to watch, a time to take your rest,
a time to open and to shut the Ports,
and at this time Stukley the gates are shut,
and till a full time shall not be oped.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Solomon says with words mild.
Spare the rod and spill the child,
Wholesome instruction, goodly discipline:
This is a simple piece of small revenge.
But this I vow who shut me out of by night,
shall never see me enter here by day.
will ye sir let the pray taken in,
For fear the Irish rescue it again.

sp.speaker: Gains.
sp.l: it were pity Sir to lose so good a pray,
And greater pity but to lose one man.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: You may let in the pray. But keep them out,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: stay Sergeant Mayor? O white livered lout,
Dost thou respect a bullock or a Jade,
More than a man to Gods own likeness mad?

sp.speaker: Harbart.
sp.l: Thou gettest not one cow to thy share,
Nor a owes tail, unless as Cacus, did,
I by the tail could draw one from the heard,
And cast her at thy head the horns and all.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Go make your Cabana underneath the wall,
And so god night.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Farewell go pick your teeth,
How glad am I my trunks are yet aboard,
Lieutenant, Autient, Fellow soldiers all,
I would we might not part but needs we must,
Tom stukely cannot brooke the least disgrace.
Tonight I will bide such venture as you shall
Let us man the bridge, the water flows apace,
If the enemy come he dare not pass the flood
So on this side we with our pray are safe.
How many Cows shall fall unto my share.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: all if ye please, your valour compassed all.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: shall all the cows be mine, I will not have one.
Thirty chief horse if you will let me have,
two ship from hence to seek a better coast.
share that amongst ye, there is a hundred pound,
and two months pay that is due unto myself.
I give you frankly, drink it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: But Captain will you leave this land indeed

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Before the son the morning doth salute
I will see my hobbies safely sent aboard,
Then follow I that scorn to be controlled,
Of any man that is meaner than a king,
farewell Oneale, if Stukly here had staid,
thy head for treason, soon thou shouldst have paid.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Oneale with a halter about his neck, and Neale Mackener after him.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: O what intends the great Oneale by this?

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.l: Neale Mackener, I do not wear this cord,
as doubting or foredooming such a death,
but thou who art my Secretary, knowest
that my unkind Rebellions merit more:
Therefore I bear this hateful cord in sign
of true Repentance, of my treasons past,
and at the Deputies feet on humble knees
will sue for pardon from her majesties:
Whose Clemency I grieve to have abuse,
what sayst thou: is it not my safest course,

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: Can I believe that mighty shane Oneale ?
Is so deject in courage as he seems
or that his dauntless dragon winged thought,
can humble them at any Princes feet.

sp.speaker: Oneale
sp.l: What can I do my forces are dispersed,
my kindred slain, my horses made a pray,
Ocean, O hanlon, and Magennis killed,
If the Queens power pursue I am but dead,
If I submit she is merciful
Her Deputy will grant me life in her behalf.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: Thou canst not tell the state offended stands
And thou condemned in every subjects eye,
And I am censured for my practises,
Rather retire thee into Clamgeboy.
Where Alexander and Mack Gilliam Buske,
May join their Scots unto thy scattered troops,
And reinforce the English with fresh power,
If not, at least thy life is safe with them:
Until thy friends may reunite themselves.

sp.speaker: Oneale.
sp.l: I would embrace thy counsel but I fear
The wrongs that I have done unto the Scots,
Sticks in the breast of Alexander Oge,
And he will take occasion of Revenge,

body.stage: Enter Alexander slge and maister Gillian Buske two Scots

sp.l: put it in proof for here comes he and Busk.
Cast off thy cord let not them see thy shame,

sp.speaker: Alex,
sp.l: Gillam the news are true of great Oneale.
Dundalke hath dashed his pride and quelled his power.

sp.speaker: Busk.
sp.l: Occasion offers us a fair Revenge,
For our dear cousin young Mack Agnus death.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Who will take revenge on weakness that is depressed?

sp.speaker: Busk.
sp.l: Whole let his kinsman's blood unwrecked rest.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Do they not see us? or disdain to see us?

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: Salute them kindly.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Gentlemen good day

body.stage: Alexander Mack Surlo and maister gillam Buske,

sp.l: Fortune hath frowned upon your friend Oneale,
My troops are beaten, by the English power,
If therefore you will join your Scottish aid,
With the remainder of my followers,
Your means may make recovery of my loss,
And you shall bind Oneale to quit your love.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: how can a Rebel or a traitor hope
Of good success against his sovereign:
Awhile perhaps he may disturb the state,
And damn himself but at the last he falls.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: I thought thou hadst despised the English churls,

sp.speaker: Busk.
sp.l: Admit he did, how can he love Oneale,
But chiefly thee that was the counsellor,
To cut off young Mack Agnus our dear cousin.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: Not my advise but his too saucy braves,
To great Oneale, did cause his cutting off.

sp.speaker: Busk.
sp.l: Speak such another word I will cut thy throat,
Thou traitorous Rebel Mackener.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Mack gilliam Buske upbraid not Neale Mackener,
I did the deed and hold it was well done,
Because he braved me in my own command,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: as thou dost us now in our own command,
For instefying of so foul a fact,
here is revenge traitors have at you both.

body.stage:
They Draw and fight, Oneale Flies, Alexander pursues
him out: Busk and Mackener fight and Mack. is slaine.

sp.l: Fliest thou thou traitorous coward Shane Oneale,
I am too light a foot to let thee scape.

sp.speaker: Busk.
sp.l: I will stop your flight, you shall not follow him,

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: I meant it not proud overweening Scot.

sp.speaker: Busk.
sp.l: have at thee then Rebellious Irishman,

body.stage: They fight Mack. is slaine. Enter Alex. with Oneales head.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I see we are victors both, Mack Gilliam Busk.
Here is the head of traitorous shane Oneale.

sp.speaker: Busk.
sp.l: And here is his bloody Secretary dead.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No force; this head for present will I send,
To that most noble English deputy,
that ministers Justice as he were a God,
and guerdons virtue like a liberal king,
This grateful present may procure our peace,
And so the English fight and our fear may cease

sp.speaker: Busk.
sp.l: And may all Irish that with treason deal,
Come to like end or worse than shane Oneale .

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Hernand with stuklie brought in with Bils. and halberds to them the Gouernors wife.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Had I known thus much Governor I would have
burnt my ships in the haven before thy face and have fed
Haddocks with my horses.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Is thou and all thou hast at my dispose and dost deny
me upon courtesy: what I may take whether
thou wilt or no. Stukly if thou be called so
I will make thee know a Governor of Cales.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Governor, will nothing but five of my horses serve
Your turn, Sirrah thou gets not one
of them, and a hair would save thy life: if I had
as many horses as there be stones in the Island
Thou shouldst not have one of them.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Know Stukly too
It had been thy duty to have offered them
and glad that I would grace thee to accept them,
what is he that dares thrust into this harbour,
And not make tender of his goods to me.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Why then know Governor, here is once one that
dares thrust into this harbour:
That will not make thee tender of a mite,
Nor cares not of a hair how thou dost take it,
I will not give one of my hobbies for thy government.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: I will be answerable to thee for thy horses,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Doest thou keep a tole-Booth: zounds doest thou
Make a horse courser of me.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Nay Sirrah then I will lay you by the heels,
And I will have them every horse of them:

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Thou gettest no so much as a nail of one of them
No, if thou wouldst draw it with thy teeth,
If you do, I will clench it with your scalp,

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Call me the Prouost hither presently

sp.speaker: Lady to one. Of the attendants.
sp.l: Sirrah is this the English gentleman Of the attendants.
Which brought the horses.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Madam it is he: this is the man:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: How do they call him:

sp.speaker: Ser,
sp.l: His Servants say, his name is Seignior Stukly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Now by my troth and as I am a Lady
I never saw a fairer Gentleman
I would it lay in my power to do him good.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Sirrah as I have seized your ships and horses,
so I commit your Body unto prison,
Until his highness pleasure shall be known,
Prouost lay Irons upon him and take him to
your charge.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Well well, for all this, might I have my will,
In faith his entertainment should be better.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: You muddy slave, you may by your power do a
Little but I will call you to a reckoning for
This Gear, and Sirrah see a horse be not
Lacking if he be: I will make thee on thy bare
Feet, lead him in a halter after me to
The furthest pare of spain.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Go to, thou art a base pirate.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Sirrah muchacho: you that have eaten a horse
And his tail hangs out of your mouth, you lie.
All that thou canst do, shall not get a horse,
If saint Iaques your saint want a horse,
he should not get one of them: he should go
A foot else all the days of his life.
By this flesh and blood, I will make thee repent it.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yet good my Lord consider what you do
Surely the confidence of this man's spirit,
Shows that his blood is either great or noble,
Or that is fortunes at his own command.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: I hold him rather to be some desperate pirate,
That thinks to domineer upon the Land
As he is used amongst his mates at Sea.
Besides, it is less disgrace to bear his braves,
here where your power is absolute and free,
And where he wholly stands at your dispose,
Than in a place indifferent to either,
And where you both should stand in equal terms.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: If I did prize his honour with mine own,
Then wife perhaps I might allow your reason,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Besides perhaps they may be for a present,
Which now his heat, restrains him to disclose,
Which should they be to any prince of Spain,
how ill it may be taken at your hands.

sp.speaker: gou.
sp.l: This his committing gives some cause to doubt,
I care not, were they sent unto the Devil,
Where the commission of my Government,
gives me as much as I demand of him,
Tomorrow I will unto the court myself:
today I have some business in the Isle.
and it will be evening ere I do return,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Prouest,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: where have you yet bestowed this gentleman

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: madam he is here within the palace yet,
Ready to go unto the marshalcy,
He had been gone but that upon some business,
I come to know his honours pleasure in:
And he is gone: but Prouest since your prisoner,
Is not departed I pray thee bring him hither,
I will see if by persuasion I can win him,
To yield and to submit unto my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam I will,

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: I thank you: give us leave a little.
Fair gentleman: but that it is too late
To call back yesterday I would have wished:
That you had dealt more kindly with my Lord,
Sir it should seem you have been unacquainted,
With the hot bloods and Temper of our Clime,
Or with a Spaniards noble disposition,
Whereas your kind submission might have wrought
What your high spleen and courage cannot do.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Fair courteous Lady, had your beauteous self
Asked anything: a noble English heart,
had made you mistress of your own desires,
But to be threatened and subjected by him
Zounds first I will fray him out on his government,
And vex his very marrow in his Bones.
Thinks he because I am fallen into his hands,
I fear his power, 'sblood I will&H1; stare his eyes out first,
he looks not one the Sun I dare not brave.
I am Stukly let him know my name,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Brave gentleman: yet I could have wished
I had but been of counsel with your thoughts,
But without breach or touch of modesty
Even for the love I bear unto your country,
Mine honour kept unstained which I protest,
I prize beyond the thing I hold the dearest,
unmanned what ever lieth in my power,
To comfort you in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.p: Madam; how much your noble Spanish courtesy hath power in me,
sp.l: A faithful English heart shall manifest,
And I will be the champion of your honour,
Where ever I become in christendom.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes know a Lady of spain can be as kind,
as any English woman of them all,
What is it Seignior I can help you with

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: my liberties the thing I most desire.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That presently I cannot warrant you,
But I will labour for it to my Lord,
With all the means my wits can all devise,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Then this Madam. might I possibly obtain, but
To work some means for me, by your best endeavours
That I may have but one of my horses that I
Will choose, and but respite for one day to
Ride a little way, upon some earnest business,
Now in the absence of your husband, and as I
am a soldier and a gentleman, and by the honours
Of my Nation: I will come back by the prefixed hour.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.p: Sir should I devise some means for the accomplishment of your desire, and that it should come to my husbands
sp.l: Ear before your return: I should hearken
for your coming back, besides if by this means,
you should seek to escape greater treasons
Might be objected, than I hope your are guilty of,
and what Danger both my life, and honour might incur
I Imagine you are not Ignorant.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Madam, if all your wits can but hide
It but from your husband, if he should come before
I return, for the other I dare pawn my
Soul to you, that I will hold my word.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: Go to, mine honour and life is your bail let your
Return be six a clock in the evening, I
Will once trust an Englishman on his word.

body.stage: (Exeunt. Enter King Phillip with him Alua and Sancto Dauila, with them the Portingall embassador.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Speak reverend intercessor for the state
Of young Sebastian king of Portugal,
What craves our dear entire beloved cousin,
Wherein we may befriend his Majesty?

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: First sacred king the Sovereign of my faith,
And Portugals undoubted supreme head,
Doth kindly greet your highness in all love,
Next on behalf of your respective care,
And the league-bound of natural amity,
Which he mistrusts not: but combines ye both
as being kinsmen he entreats this boon:
That whereas lately from the King of Fez,
Muly Mahamet, to my royal master,
Hath honourable embassage been sent
And great entreaty made to crave his aid,
against Mullucco brother to that king,
Who now intrudes upon Mahamets bounds,
and building on his privilege of age,
and inequality of matchless strength,
strives to deprive him of his diadem,
It would seem good unto your princely self,
was in the like we shall be ready still,
at spain's entreaty to assist my lord,
With some such necessary strength of war,
As in this action may conclude a peace,
to Portugal great profit and renown.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: are then Molucco and his brother king,
at civil mutiny among themselves:

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: They are my Lord, and many woeful days
the afflicted Barbary hath suffered spoil,
and been a prey unto her natural Subjects.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The right is in Molucco: wherefore then
Would Prince Sebastian aid the other part?
Beside, Mahamet is an Infidel,
From whose associate fellowship in this
and all things else we Christians must refrain.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: Grace but his reasons with your mild conceit,
Whereon he grounds his lawful resolution,
and mighty Philip you shall quickly find
this his intent to be most honourable:
Not for regard of any supreme claim
the stern Mahamet lays unto the Crown,
Nor any Justice that in his behalf
May be presumed upon, doth stout Sebastian
List to this motion, but for honours sake,
For Portugals chief good, and to advance
the christian true Religion through those parts,
Is he inclined to undertake this war.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How can that be: acquaint us with your meaning.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: This worthy king: it is not unknown to you,
that divers towns and cities situate
Within the borders of rich Barbary,
Which king Emanuell conquered by his sword
and left appropriate still to be enjoyed,
of such as should be kings in Portugal.
Or, but by this prevention like to fall,
and be confiscate to the Moore again,
but by an army thither brought in time,
not only these great cities shall be kept,
But raising this Mahamet to the crown,
And quite distinguishing his brothers claim
When we have planted him: and that by us,
The country is subdued and kept in awe,
We shall not only still retain our own
But for Mahamet to subscribe to us,
And either he and his change their faith,
and worship that eternal god we do,
and disanulling be deprived of life,
And so assume the Government ourselves.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: This tastes of honour and of policy
Might it with like success be brought to pass.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: With your assistance: there is no doubt my lord
But what we have imagined shall ere long,
be truly and effectually performed.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Aye, But Mulluccos Army doth consist
Of Dreadless Turks and Warlike Saracens,
Is much to be suspected in this case.

sp.speaker: Bot,
