sp.l: What can they do though great their number be
When for their single force we come in strength,
Of Spain, of Portugal, and Barbary.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your reasons have prevailed, what power is it
Our loving cousin doth request of us.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: Of horse and foot indifferently commixed,
Only ten thousand will supply his want.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: (Botellio, so I take it you are called)
Give place a while till with our faithful lord.
We have advised us better on the cause,
and then you shall have answer presently.
Now you supporters of our royal state,
Alua: and Sanct Danulo, briefly show,
What your opinion is touching the suit
Of neighbouring Portugal fame-thirsty king.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: That he attempts an enterprise my liege,
Will sooner break his neck than make him great,

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: That hereby if occasion be laid hold on,
That Spain and Portugal shall be unite,
And you the Sovereign ruler of them both

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Express thy meaning Danulo in that point,

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: It shall not need I stand on circumstance,
Your highness knows Sebastian once removed,
The way is open solely for yourself,
Either by force or by corrupting gold,
To step into the throne, now for a mean
To cut him off: what better way than this,
To sooth his purpose and to draw him on
With expectation of a strong supply,
But when he is set forth upon his way,
And left his country that without reproach,
And scandal to his name, he cannot retire,
Then to proclaim on pain of speedy death,
that not a Spaniard seem to join with him,
So landed once in desert Baberie,
His weakened soldiers and himself at once,
shall fall before Mulluccos conquering sword.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Mean space to colour your intent the better,
Muster your men as if you meant to aid him,
But with these men as soon as he is gone,
approach the borders of fair Portugal,
That if it chance Sebastian do survive,
the pagans sword: yet in his absence we
may enter his dominions sack his towns.
and take possession of the realm by force.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Withal dispatch, ambassadors to Rome,
and forthwith to entreat the Popes advice,
Who in no wise before hand we are sure,
Will licence any christian potentate,
to traffic or converse with heathen kings,
and so his prohibition may excuse,
and serve to cloak your breach of promise with.
When it is perceived you do do not aid Sebastian

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You counsel well and fitting our desire,
That many years have wished that portugal,
And fruitful Castile being one continent,
Had likewise been the subject of one Sceptre,
Call forth the ambassador as you have said.
So will we dally with our cousin's suite,
My Lord Botellio we have weighed the effect
Of your embassage and in nature bound,
Beside the affection of near neighbour-hood,
To do our kinsman and your noble king,
All offices of kindness that we can,
Tell him from us we only not commend,
His haughty mind in this attempt of his,
But his discreet and politic proceeding,
And will therein to further his intent,
Aid him with twice five thousand armed soldiers,
And fifty galleys all well furnished,
Which on the fourth of June near to the straights,
Of Gibraltar in a haven there,
Called Ell Porto the Sancto Maria,
shall wait his coming on toward Apheryca.
So wishing him a happy prosperous brother,
In all we may, we live to do him good.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: Thanks to the high and mighty king of Spain,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Lord Sancto Danulo, bring him on his way.
and Alua now what think ye of this plot.
Is it not too severe, ambitious
and more deceitful than becomes a King.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: a kingdoms thirst hath to dispense my Lord,
With any rigour or extremity.
and that which in mean men would seem a fault,
as leaning to ambition or such like,
Is in a king but well beseeming him.
Upon my life your grace hath well resolved
And howsoever vulgar wits repine.
yet regal majesty must have his course.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Danulo: what news you are so soon returned?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: A gallant Englishman my gracious Lord,
Haughty in look and hasty in his business
But now arrived at the court gate,
Earnestly craves admittance to your presence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: An English Gentleman let him draw near.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Right high and mighty: if to kings installed,
And sacredly anointed it belong
To minister true justice and relieve
the poor oppressed stranger, then from thee
Renowned Phillip, that by birth of place,
Upholds the Sceptre of a Royal king,
Stukley a soldier and a Gentleman,
But neither like a soldier nor a man,
Of some of thy unworthy subjects handled:
Doth challenge Justice at thy sacred hands,
And succour against oppression offered him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oppression offered and by some of ours.

sp.speaker: Stukt
sp.l: Yes royal Phillip and in some respect
The vile abuse doth touch your majesty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stand up and tell the manner of thy grief
And on our royal name we promise thee,
The offender shall be sharply punished.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: A lusty man believe me of his limes.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Aye and as knightly in his talk beside,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Thus kingly Phillip having served of late,
Under my princes army in the field,
against the rude rebellious Irish: where
Upon desire to travel and especially,
Upon affection that I had to see
your princely court so honourably famed:
As also to make tender of my love,
and duteous service to your majesty,
Shipping myself with other private goods
Which I had purchased by my diute of sword,
I came to Cales: where landed with my pray,
In number thirty hobbies for the shore,
One Don Herando there your govenor,
attacheth both my ship and all therein,
and though I tell them that the hobbies were,
a present for your grace and for that cause,
I thither brought them, yet the uncivil Lord,
Because he might not have one horse of them,
To his own use, clapped irons one my heels,
and in a dungeon like a gripple churl,
I think his purpose was to Famish me,
But that by strange adventure and good hap,
I scaped his tyrant fingers: hoping here,
If I might once get opportunity,
To let your highness understand thereof,
I should find remedy against his wrong.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Have we such base ignoble substitutes,
That dare so heinously oppress a stranger,
and such a one as came to offer us,
The bounty of his heart in friendly gifts?
Let there be sent a messenger forthwith
To bring the wretch to answer his abuse,
and Stukley welcome to king Phillips court,
Repose thyself: thou shalt have right with me,
and favour too again thine enemy.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: I thank your Majesty: but must entreat.
You would Vouchsafe to pardon me in this
I needs must back again to cales my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be not afraid, thy goods shall be purloined,
There is not a mite but he shall bring it forth.
Or of his own purse make it good to thee,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: It is not that and please your Majesty,
But I have past my word I will return,
And Stukley holds his promise as religion,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well then my Lord of Alua give in charge,
Some of our pensioners attend on him,
To bring Herando hither safely guarded,

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: It shall be done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What shall we do, the time draws on,
The English captain promised to return,
But yet he comes not: if my Lord should miss him
My life were lost, your credit thereby cracked,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Content thee Prouost: such apparent sign
Of manly disposition, shine in him,
Of valour, gentry, and what not beside,
As I presume if he remain alive,
He will return at his prefixed hour:
As yet the respite that was granted him,
Is not expired I do not doubt ere then,
But he will rid us of the fear we are in.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Had we but Madam, known which way he went,
Or had himself told us of the place,
To which he purposed to make his Journey,
There had been yet some comfort and some hope,
But ignorant of both how can we choose,
But be suspicious and almost despair.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Thou talkest absurdly? had we known the place
The cause which made him and which way he went,
What thank were that to us to let him go,
Where we were sure to find him out again,
Or how should trial of his faith appear,
In matters of no weight or jeopardy?
Now being so that of our free accord
Without the least respect but to his promise,
He was dismissed and that he clearly sees,
It is at his charge to stay on his return,
And yet will unconstrained keep his vow,
approves him truly loyal, us truly loving.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: If I be called in question for his absence,
Madam I must rely upon your wit,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Be that thy refuge here Herando comes.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Prouost I have bethought me at the last,
How to dispose of Stukley and his goods,
part of his horses I will give the king,
and part I will bestow upon my friends,
To these conditions if he condescend,
I am content he shall have liberty,
and he, his ship, and men be so discharged.
But otherwise I will cause his ship be sunk,
and he and his as pirates suffer death.
Therefore go fetch him to me presently,
I may be certain if he will yield or no.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Ah Madam I am strucken dumb and dead?
What shall I answer to my Lords demand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Be not so fearful lest thy guilty looks,
argue suspicion of some treachery,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Doest hear me Prouost fetch me Stukley forth,

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Make it as though thou understands him not.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Madam what whispers he into your ear,
that he neglects to do as I command.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He tells me my Lord: the English captain,
Is grown submissive and very tractable,
and of himself is ready to resign,
as much as you require to have of him,
and that even now after his counsel heard,
How best he might crave pardon for his pride,
His stiff resistance, and audacious words,
Whereto he answered that his readiest way,
Was by petition to Solicit yon,
and so he tells me, that he left him studying,
How to intend some quaint conceited method,
Might draw Remorse from your displeased mind.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Is he Prouost, become flexible?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Exceeding mild and penitent my Lord,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I thought his stomach would come down at last,
Go bid him save a labour with his pen,
and tell him we are here, let it suffice
If with his tongue he do recant his fault.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Nay let him write for writing will remain
When words but spoken may be soon forgot,
It makes the better on your side my Lord,
That under-neath his hand it shall appear,
By his consent and not by your constraint,
he made surrender of his prize to you,
So shall the world what after chance to fall,
Clear your extortion and abuse.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It cannot be but he hath done ere this,
I prithee see: much matter in few lives,
Is quickly caught by one of meaner wit,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: It were not good to trouble him so soon.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I will not subject my desire herein,
and wait upon his leisure look I say.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: Without some cunning shift we are undone.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Why stayest thou Prouost when I bid thee go.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: With draw thyself to satisfy his mind,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Help my excuse, sweet Madam, if I fail.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: Let me alone: my lord, how glad am I,
There shall be now atonement of this strife,
and that this English gentleman is pleased.
To yield obedience and yourself as willing
To be appeased at his humility.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I tell thee wife he stooped in happy time,
Or all submission else had come too late,
Where is he Prouost? will he come to us:

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: Is he not yet returned.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam not yet.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: Then do I fear our plot will be discovered.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Why speakest not man? where is thy prisoner?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He hath not yet my Lord set down his mind,
he doth entreat your honour staye awhile,
and he will then have made an end of all.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I will wait no longer on his mastership,
Give me the key I will fetch him forth myself,

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: What will you do, you fetch him forth yourself,
I would not that for all the wealth in spain,
will you so much annoy your vital powers,
as to oppress them with the prison stink,
You shall not if you love me come so near:
The place is mortally infected lately,
and as the Prouost tells me divers die,
Of strange diseases, and no longer since
than the last morning, two were buried thence?
ask him me Lord if this be true or no.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It is most certain there are many sick,
and therefore good my Lord refrain the place.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Unless thou bring him straight way to my sight,
Nor danger nor entreaty shall prevail,
But I will enter at the door myself.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: See once again it may be his come,
Mean space I will hold him with some other talk.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Do gentle Madam.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: If he be not come,
protract the time as much as in thee lies.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will tarry long enough: never doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Sirrah before thou go: bring him forth,
Or look to lie in irons as he doth.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: I have not seen you often times my Lord,
So out of patience and so far from quiet,
You were not wont in things as great as this,
But that you would be persuaded by my words.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I cannot tell how I may think of you,
Your busying of yourself so much herein,
and speaking for this Englishman so oft,
Makes me suspect more than I thought to do.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: suspect as how, that I do favour him,
Or is it your meaning that I go about.
To set him free, your best accuse me flatly,
That I have taught him here to break the prison,
Is this the recompense for my good will,
Have I this thank for being Provident,
and careful for your health? go where you will,
suspect thyself and me, cut short thy days
Do anything that may disparage you,
hereafter I will learn to hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: how now my love, what angry for a word?

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: have I not reason when you grow suspicious,
Of me that am yourself your bosom friend.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I prithee be content I meant no harm,
I know thou wouldst not prejudice my state,
to be the empress of all asia here

body.stage: (Now he comes. Enter Stukly in Gyues.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: then do I cast off fear,
and whilst I live hereafter will I trust,
an Englishman the better for his sake.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Where is the submission that ye told me of,
call ye this repentance for his pride.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Uh at craves the unjust governor of calls.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Obstinate captain that thou lend thy knee,
and make surrender of what I require,
Or thou and thine like pirates all shall die.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: I cannot hear, I would you would speak louder.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Doest thou deride me.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Not deride you Sir.
But for my hobbies I will not spare a hair,
So much of their tales, to pick your teeth,

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: Sweet captain speak him fair at my entreaty.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Madam I owe my life to do you service
But for his threats I do not care a rush.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: How have I been deluded by your words,
he scorns me still, knock off his iron gyues,
and let an Executioner be sent for
I will not stir until I see him dead.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Herando, I do dare the worst thou canst.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: O do not provoke him so.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: content you Madam, Stukley bears a mind,
that will not melt at any tyrants words.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: callest thou me tyrant too, it is enough,
In sooth I will try your patience for that word.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Herando, In his majesties high name,
I charge you presently prepare yourself,
to make appearance at the court this night,
and bring this gentleman your prisoner here,
together with such horses as you have.
Of his in your possession: fail you not
As you will answer it unto your peril.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: how knows the king he was my prisoner,

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: What answer make ye will you go with me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: With all my heart: this Stukely is some devil
And with his sorcery hath incensed the king,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Hernando, if your Lordship want a horse,
One of my Hobbies is at your command.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: he flatters me: But I must dissemble with him
brave Seignior stukly what so ever hath past,
Betwixt yourself and me conceive the best
It was but trial of your fortitude,
and now I see you are no less indeed
Than what you see me a valiant gentleman,
I do embrace you with a brothers love,
Come let us go I will do you any grace,
Unto the King my honer extends unto,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: when I do need it, I will thank ye Sir.
But Madam wherein may I quittance you,
whose kindness is the cause of all my good.

sp.speaker: lady.
sp.l: I crave not more for anything I do,
But that you virtuously report of me,
and in remembrance of me wear this scarf.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: This on mine arm, yourself within my heart,
Doth Stukly vow perpetually to bear.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Vernon and a Maister of a ship with the lantado and two or three officers.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Seignior Lantado by your patience,
It is no wrack: nor you by law can seize,
upon the ship or goods here cast away.

sp.speaker: lant.
sp.l: Sir, Sir, your negative is of no force
you are part-owner happily of the ship,
Or else capemarchaut ventured in the fraght,
Your speech is partial to save ship and goods.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Examine then the master of his oath?

sp.speaker: lant.
sp.l: So we intend.

sp.speaker: Ship. M.
sp.l: Sir you have known me long,
and never knew me falsify my word,
Much less mine oath, which I will freely pawn,
My life and all to testify the truth

sp.speaker: lant.
sp.l: Whence was the ship.

sp.speaker: Ship. Ma.
sp.l: Of London?

sp.speaker: lant.
sp.l: What her name.

sp.speaker: ship. M.
sp.l: The Pelican?

sp.speaker: lant.
sp.l: What burden was she of.

sp.speaker: Ship M.
sp.l: Two hundred tonne.

sp.speaker: lant.
sp.l: And what her Lading?

sp.speaker: M Ship.
sp.l: Packs of English cloth,
This gentleman ought neither ship nor goods
But came from Britain as a passenger,
For at Saint mallowes we had cause to touch
To take a board a merchants Factor there,
and there we found this honest gentleman.
very desirous to be shipped for Spain.
In luckless hour he brought his trunks aboard,
and in more helps time the same are lost,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: small loss were that if all the rest were safe,
The men are lost only we two survive.
Whom you by shows of pity, have enforced,
to come ashore and leave the crazed ship,
And will ye now forget what you have sworn?
and seek to make a wrack of that is none.
set us abroad again and let us bide,
The hazzard of the tempest and the tide.

sp.speaker: Lant.
sp.l: Ye are ashore, and thank me for your lives,
Which said, why should you value ship or goods?
You swear you are but passenger, let pass
let the owners and the merchant fear the loss

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.l: What if he should? The master there am I,
and were I dead, if any did survive
and live aboard, you cannot make awrack,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No I will kneel before the king of Spain.
Before my Country men such loss sustain

sp.speaker: Lant.
sp.l: proud English man since thou art peremptory.
Thou shalt nor kneel nor see his majesty,

body.stage: Away wtih them Trumpets sound. Enter king Phillip: leaning on Stuklees. Shoulder, Alua, Dauita, Valdes that was the messenger, Hernando before bare, and the Gouernor. Hernando after (with other.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Heroic Stukly, on our royal word
We never did esteem a present more,
Than those fair Irish horse of your frank gift.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Redoubted Phillip Royal Catholic king,
It pleaseth so the Bounty of your spirit,
To reckon them that that are of little worth,
But if your highness know my inward zeal,
To do you service past the worlds compare,
You would esteem those thirty Irish Jades,
As thirty mites to all the Indian mines.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: How we esteem your present and yourself,
Our instant favours shall advertise you.
Alua and Sancto Danula shall declare,
To gallant Stukley what regard we bear,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Cross of all Crosses why should sea and wind,
Spare me to live where double death is assigned,
Is it possible that Stukley so deject,
In England? lives in Spain in such respect.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Stay what are these.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Poor suitors to your grace,
An English ship is split here in the Race,
And this Lantado the Vice-admiral,
Coming aboard and seeing us alive,
The sole remainder of a hundred Souls,
Enticed us by christian promises,
to come ashore as pitying our case,
Our feet no sooner touched this Spanish earth,
Than he would make a wrack of ship and goods.

sp.speaker: Lant.
sp.l: Dread Sovereign true, the ship is split and sunk
and every billow over-rakes the hull,
this living couple crept up to the poop,
In dread of danger and of present death,
In charity I took to save their lives.

sp.speaker: Ship. M.
sp.l: With promise and proviso gracious king,
that no advantage should be taken thereof,
Else had I staid though he had gone ashore,

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Why, what are you.

sp.speaker: Ship. M.
sp.l: The Master of the ship.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: And he the owner or the venturerer,
and would deceive us of our royalty.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Upon my life great King I meant it not,
I am no Owner nor yet venturer,
I came but in her as a passenger,
But afore I saw the tide was at the highest,
and ebbing water would have laid us dry,
The ship belonging to my place of birth,
I was resolved to bide the utmost brunt,
and save the ship and goods for the English owners,

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Whereof you may be one.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Hear me great king,
If you believe this breast have any spark,
Of honour or of Vulgar honesty,
Then credit me this gentleman that speaks,
Was never owner of a ship in his life.
Nor Merchant venturer though both trades be good.
But well derived of rich and gentle birth,
Holds it his bliss to be a traveller,

sp.speaker: K. Phil
sp.l: Your Protestations have persuaded us
Lantado leave them and discharge the ship,
and gentleman, and shipper stay without,
This honourable countryman of yours,
shall bring our further pleasure for your good.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If in the Basilisks fore-prizzing eye,
Be safety for the object it beholds,
Then Stukley may to Vernon comfort bring,
Else men are safe at Sea when Sirens sing.

body.stage: Exit Vernon Ship Maister and Landato.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Now gallant Stukley, boast of Phillips grace,
By such employments as we have assigned,
The king our cousin Don Sebastian,
Solicits us for aid to Africa,
In hope to conquer the Barbarians.
The farther Princes of that parched soil,
Are at contention Who shall wear the crown,
And the young King of Portugal believes,
And so do we, their strife shall breed him peace,
And for he stands engaged by Royal oath,
To help the king Fez against his foe.
And craves assistance from us of his blood
We have consented with condition,
to give it him if Rome doth hold it fit:
and you brave Stukley are the man select,
to carry to the Pope our Embassy,
and we will furnish you for these affairs,
Do not admire the strangeness of our choice,
In pointing you before our native nobles,
But think our love, our hope, or your desert,
Or all conjoined advance you to this place.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Most sacred and mighty king of Spain,
though many reasons might with stand belief
that you would choose me your ambassador,
Yet since your highness twice hath spoke the word,
I humbly credit and accept the charge.

sp.speaker: K Phil.
sp.l: and to defray your charge in our affairs,
Our bounty shall exceed her usual bounds:
First for it is the time of Gubilie,
Next for you go from Phillip King of Spain,
and last for high regard we hold you in?

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: With favour I will study to deserve.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: It is deserved: Valdes deliver you,
Five thousand Ducats to Don stukleyes hands,
Here are our letters and commission,
with such Instruction as concern the cause,
So much for that: now for your countrymen,
whose ship miscarried here upon our coast
we do allow them all convenient help,
For your sake to recover ship and goods,
and that their loss may seem so much the less.
We do acquit them of all custom fees,
So gallant Stukley carry them these news,
and make you ready for these great affairs.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Ready to serve and follow your command

sp.speaker: K Phil.
sp.l: Are not these English like their country fish,
Called gudgeons? that will bite at every bate?
how easily the credulous fools believe,
The thing they fancy, or would wish of chance,
Using no precepts of art prospective,
To see what end each project sorteth to,
Hernandes tell me what is thy conceit,
Of our election and of Stukleys worth?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Most gracious and dread sovereign pardon me,
To speak of Stukly in particular,
Because your frown lies heavy one me yet,
For that I did and offered him at Cales,
But generally I censure the Engish thus,
hardy, but rash, witty, but overweening
Else would this English hot brain weigh the intent
Your highness hath in thus employing him

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou judgest rightly, it is not for love,
We bear this nation that we grace him thus,
but use him as the agent of our guile,
For if the matter were of great import,
Or that we would keep touch with Portugal,
and aid his voyage into Barbary,
Stukley should have no hand in these affairs,
but now we deal as Lords of Insureds use,
stop with one bush two gaps into their ground,
One must we send to Rome to Jubilee,
and Stukley for his gift must have reward,
One bounty gilded with employments grace,
Serves both the turns, and sends proud Stukley hence,
Ualdes, five thousand Ducats pay him that,
So are we rid of a fond Englishman.

body.stage:
(Exit Omnes.
Enter Stukly, with Vernon and the Ship Maistar.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: But is it certain that my wife is dead.

sp.speaker: Ship. M.
sp.l: Sure as I live I saw her buried,
First died the mother, then the daughter next
Then old Sir Thomas Curteis lived not long
And died not rich: but what was left, he gave
Part to his brother, part to the hospital.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Then where is the part he left his son in law.

sp.speaker: Ship. M.
sp.l: Pardon me sir he left no part for you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your part and grand part were consumed too soon,
To have a portion left you at the last,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Friend Vernon leave such discontenting speech
your melancholy over flows your spleen,
Even as the billows over rack your ship,
Whose loss the king for my sake will restore,
Then tax me not good Vernon with grand parts,
What is twenty thousand pound to a free heart.
Twenty weeks charges for a gentleman,
A thousand pound a week is but fair expense.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: your wife died not worth such a weeks expense.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: What remedy yet Stukly will not want,
she is gone and all her friends their heads are laid
Good resurrection have they at the last,
then shall we meet again: In the mean space,
Tom Stukly lives, lusty Tom Stukly,
Graced by the greatest king of christendom.

sp.speaker: Nuntio.
sp.l: the governor of Cales Hernandes stays
to cry you mercy and to take his leave,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: there let him stay I leave him to himself
I love him not nor malice one so mean.
the king don Stukly prays to speak with you,
But even a word, he will not stay you long,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: I shall attend his highness by and by
For old acquaintance and for Country sake,
Vernon and master, let me Banquet you,
It shall be no disgrace to feast with me,
Whom the king useth with so great respect.

sp.speaker: ship. M.
sp.l: Pardon sir, I must go see my ship,
Whose owner shall be thankful for your favour.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: What says master Vernon.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I, some other time,
May trouble you although it be not now.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: As your occasions shall induce you sir

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Good master see if anything of mine,
May from the ship be safely brought ashore,
And I will see your pains considered.

sp.speaker: ship. M.
sp.l: I do not doubt but all your stuff is safe,
The hatches are as close as any chest.
Nothing takes hurt but what is in the hold,
Because the keel is split upon the sands,
I will send your trunks ashore and then provide,
to seek our drowned men and to bury them,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not all the drowned, but those are drowned and dead,
for I am drowned in my conceit alive,
Some sin of mine hath so offended heaven
that heaven still sends offence unto mine eye.
What should I think of Stukly or myself,
either was he created for my scourge,
or I was born the foil to his fair haps.
or in our birth our stars were retrograde.
In Ireland there he braved his Governor,
In Spain he is Companion to the king,
His fortunes mounts and mine stops to the ground,
he as the Vine, I as the Colewort Grow,
I live in every air but where he breaths,
his eye is as the Gorgons head to me,
and doth transform my senses into stone.
some hold Spain's climate to be very hot,
I feel my blood congealed to ice in Spain,
The Leopard lives not near the Elephant,
Nor I near Stukley, Spain farewell to thee,
Either I will range this universe about,
Or I will be where Stukley hath no being.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Stukley, Valdes, stuklys Page. and one bearing Bags sealed.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: How many Ducats did the king assign?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Five thousand,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Are they all within these Bags?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well near.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: how near?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Perhaps some twenty want.

body.stage: The Bags are set one the Table.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Why should there want a Marmady? a mite?
Doth the king know that any Ducats lacks,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: he doth and saw the bags would hold no more,
and sealed them with his signet as you see,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Valdes return them I will have none of them,
And tell thy master the great king of Spain,
I honour him but scorn his niggardice,

body.stage: Cast the Bags to the ground.

sp.l: And spurn abridged bounty with my foot,
a bate base twenty from five thousand Ducats,
I will give five thousand ducats to my boy,
If I had promised Phillip all the world
Or any kingdom england sole except,
I would have perished or performed my word,
and not reserved one cottage to myself,
Nor so much ground as would have made my grave,
Footer for ducats if he take the tithe,
Tell him I will do his business at Rome,
upon my proper cost but for his crowns,
Since they come curtailed carry them again
Come boy to horse, away, spaniard farewell,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Stay Sir I pray ye till I move the king.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Thou must a mountain sooner than my mind,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What a high spirit hath this Englishman,
He tunes his speeches to a kingly key,
conquers the world, and cast it at his heels,

body.stage: Enter King Phillip and his Lords.

sp.l: Here comes the king.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How now is Stukley gone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Gone and will do your business at Rome
though he refused the Ducats you assigned.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Because that twenty Ducats want.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Amongst five thousand may not twenty lack,

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: No no, he supposeth you repent your gift,
If you abridge your bounty but a mite.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not for the world shall Stukley go without,
Go add a thousand Ducats more to these,
and post and pray him not to be displeased,
Tell him I did it but to try his mind,
which I commend above my treasury,
If England have but Fifty thousand such,
the power of Spain their coast shall touch,
come Lords to horse to Cyuilt lies our way,
Ualdes I charge you to eschew delay.

body.stage: (Exeunt Omnes. Enter Sebastian, Antonia, Herando, the Cardnall and Botellio.

sp.speaker: seba.
sp.l: the great and honoured promise thou returnest us,
From our brave kinsman Philip king of Spain,
My Dear Botellio adds a second life:
unto the action that we have in hand,
the joyful breath that issues from thy lips,
Comes like a lusty gale to stuff our sails,
curling the smooth brows of the Africa deep,
O let me hear thy tongue sound once again,
the cheerful promise, of our new supplies,

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: Why thus imperial Spain bad me return,
Unto the great puissant Portugal:
Ten thousand foot: of gallant Spanish blood,
Men born in honour? and exploits in war,
And not on Indian or Base bastard Moore;
Fifty his galleys, of the proudest Vessels,
That to this day yet ever Bare an Ore
To meet you at the Port The sant Maria,
The fourth of June.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: The fourth of June, at Port The sant Maria
Ten thousand foot, and fifty of his Galleys,
By land and sea, and at a certain time,
O what a gallant harmony is here,
Methinks that I could stand and still repeat them,
A month together, they so please my soul,
Ha Antonio: O what an armies here,

body.stage: Turning to the king of Portingall,

sp.l: I tell thee cousin: never christian King,
Cam with so proud a power to Africa

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: And yet the Greatness of your royal spirit,
Makes all this nothing, so your glory shines,
above the power of spain and Portugal.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: cousin Antonio. to pay Bottello back,
The interest of his spanish embassy,
as you have taken muster of our powers,
Report the number what our army is.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Unto your number of Ten thousand spaniards
In the kings army: add to this Bottellio:
Three thousand mercenary spanish Moors,
Of voluntary valiant Portugal,
Three thousand three score special men of arms,
The Garrison of Taieer, and light horsemen,
Five thousand and four hundred,
Five thousand Germans and Italians,
My power three thousand and the Duke Averos,
Doubles my number, if fully more
Besides the power that we do expect from Rome,
thirty seven thousand we are now complete.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Our army Joined with that Mahamet brings,
his Barbarians, and his Mountain Moors,
Brought from the Deserts of burnt africa,
His valiant Turks: trained up in spoil of war,
his soldiers of Morocco and of sirus:
To fifty thousand as his promise is.
Ha Brave Antonio there will be a power,
to affright the very walls of Fes,
and make stout africa tremble at the fight,
Where we shall brave her on the sun burned plains
and with our cannons crush her wanton head,
O my Antonio how I long to see,
how spanish blood and turkish will agree.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: How shall it please your sacred Majesty,
to appoint the serially charges of this war.

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: Cousin antonio in this heat of war,
for the safety of our royal kingdom,
Let us yet speak of things concern our peace,
although but brief. first our dearest cousin,
for your princely self,
your right unto the crown of Portugal,
as first and nearest of our royal blood,
that should we fail: the next in our succession,
it is you and yours, to sit upon our throne,
Which is our pleasure to be published.

sp.speaker: anto.
sp.l: Long may my liege and sovereign Lord Sebastian,
Sit on the royal throne of portugal.

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: we thank you princely cousin,
Our dear and reverent uncle Cardinal,
unto ourself commit our wars in africa,
for the great trust we repose in you
We do bequeath our kingdoms government,
As one whose wisdom and Nobility,
Deserves the great protection of our Realm.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: The most unworthy of that royal place,
Whose many years and imbecility,
are but too weak to underprop the burthen
But may the remnant of my age be spent,
To Portugals relief and your content.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Now Antonie unto our several charges,
yourself will share the fortunes in these wars,
we do commit a Garrison of Tanieers,
unto the leading of Aluares Peres,
our voluntary Portugal to Lodouico Ceasar,
the mercenary spaniards to alonzo,
Mereneces Lieutenant general of our forces,
Tanara for the German colonel,
and now set forward let our Ensigns fly,
Either victorious, or if conquered die.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Thus far through patience of your gentle ears
hath Stukleys life in Comic history
Been new revived, that long ago lay racked
in dust of Africa with his body there:
Thus far upon the steps of high promotion
his happy stars advanced him. Now at highest
as clearest summer days have darkest nights,
and everything must finish: So in him
his state declining draws unto an end,
For by the Pope created as you heard
Marquess of Ireland: with that new honour,
Embarked and victualled think him on the Sea:
and that the time sebastian had set down
to meet with Philips promised aid is past:
Toward Africa he, toward Ireland the other,
are both addressed upon the boisterous waves:
But meeting what strange accident befell,
How he was altered from his first intent,
And he deluded by the hope he had,
To be ascribed by the Castyle King,
Regard this show and plainly see the thing.

body.stage: Enter at one doore Phillip King of spaine, Alua and souldiors they take their stand: then Enter another way, sebastian, Don Antonio, Avero with drumes and ensines they likewise take their stande. Afrer some pawse Antonio is sent forth to Phillip, who with obeysance done approching away againe very disdainfully: and as the spanish souldiors are about to follow Antonio, Phillip with his drawn sword stops them and so departs. Whereat sebastian makes showe of great displeasure, but whispering with his lords each incoraging other as they are about to to depart. Enter stukly and his Italian band: who keping aloof, sebastian sends Antonio to him, with whom stukley drawes neere towarde the king, and hauing awhile conferd, at last retirs to his souldiors, to whom he makes show of perswading them to ioyn with the portugeese: at first they seeme to mislike but last they yeelde and so both armie meeting imbrace when with a sudden Thunder-clap the sky is one fire and the blazing star appears which they prognosticating to be fortunat departed very ioyfull.

sp.l: So far was Phillip as you have beheld,
from Lending aid unto the Portuguese,
Is not content to undergo the Blot,
Of breach of promise but with naked sword,
Of unavoided Justice threatens such,
As should but offer to depart the Land.
Whereby the prince though very much disturbed,
Yet not dismayed so haughty was his mind,
Resolveth still to prosecute his Journey,
and whilst they are debating on the cause,
stukly by weather is driven in to them,
Who being known what countryman he was,
What ships he had and what Italian bands,
and whereto he was bound: the offence thereof,
the great dishonour and Impiety,
Laid open by Sebastian, straight recants,
and moves his soldiers which with much ado,
at last are won to make for Barbary,
No sooner was this fellowship contrived,
and they had joined their armies both in one:
But heaven displeased with their rash enterprise,
Sent such a fatal comet in the air,
Which they misconstruing shone successfully,
and haste the faster furrowing through the deep,
and now suppose but woe the wretched hour,
and woe that damned Mahamet whose guile,
this tender and unskilled yet valiant king,
Was thus allured unto a timeless death,
that in Tyrill a town in Barbary,
they all are landed: and not far from thence
Do meet that straggling fugitive the Moore,
With some small forces: what doth then ensue,
we may discourse but christendom shall Rue.

body.stage: (Exit. Enter muly mahamet with Calipolis drawne in their chariot, with them a messenger from sebastian.

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: Go let ten thousand of our guard be sent,
to entertain the great Sebastian,
and welcome christian to the king of Fesse,
and tell the portugal thy royal master,
that africa makes obeysance to his feet,
and stops her proud head lower than his knee,
tell him mine eyes are thirsty for his presence.

sp.speaker: mes.
sp.l: I will return to tell your highness pleasure.

sp.speaker: maha.
sp.l: Do so begone.
and let our chariot be drawn softly forward,
where I and my Calipolis will sit,
to grace the entrance of great portugal.
Now fair Calipolis rouse thy proud beauty,
and strike their eyes with verder of thyself.

body.stage: He leaps from his Chariot. Enter sebastian at the sound of Trumpets

sp.l: Dismount thee Muly from thy chariot wheels
to entertain the mighty christian king,
welcome Sebastian king of portugal.

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: thanks to the mighty and imperial fesse,
why thus alights the mighty emperor.

sp.speaker: muly.
sp.l: that I will do great portugal the grace,
to set thee by Calipolis my Queen.

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: Let mighty Mulis self supply that place,
and give me leave to attend upon your love.

sp.speaker: muly.
sp.l: Mount thee Sebastian Muly doth command,
It is my pleasure I will have it so,
Mount thee brave Lord and sit thee on her side,
and say Sebastian that the son of Phoebus,
upon his fathers fiery burnished carr,
Never sat so glorious, as the portugal,
Jove would exchange his Sceptre for thy seat,
and would abandon Juno's godlike bed,
Might he enjoy my fair Calipolis,
Welcome Sebastian love to africa.

sp.speaker: Calip.
sp.l: All welcome that Calipolis can give,
To the renowned mighty Portuguese,
here sit sweet prince and rest thee after toil,
I will wipe thy Brows with leaves more sweet and soft,
Than is the down of Cithereas fans,
I will fan thy face, with the delicious plumes,
Of that sweet wonder of Arabia,
With precious waters I will refresh thy curls,
Whose very savour shall make Panthers wild,
and lively smell of those Delicious sweets
and with such glorious liquors please thy taste,
As Helens goblet, never did contain,
Nor never graced the banquets of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Muli.
sp.l: Then speak the comfort of great Mulies life
her teeth more white, than Cancase frosty clots,
where she unlocks the portals of her lips,
Beauty a Phoenix burneth in her eye,
Which there still liveth, as it still doth die.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Why here is a gallant, here is a king indeed,
He speaks all Mars tut let me follow such a
Lad as this: This is pure fire.
Every look he casts flasheth like lightning,
There is mettle in this Boy.
He brings a breath that sets our sails on fire,
Why now I see we shall have cuffs indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now afore God, he is a gallant Prince,

sp.speaker: Muli.
sp.l: What Princes be these in your company?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: That is our cousin Prince Antonio,
The other Stukley the brave Irish Marquess.

sp.speaker: Muli.
sp.l: Noble Antonio, and renowned Marquess,
ten thousand welcomes into Africa.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thanks to great Muly.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: To your mightiness.

sp.speaker: Muli.
sp.l: Next now the neighing of our warlike horse
Shall shake the palace of commanding Jove,
Our roaring Canons tear the highest clouds,
and fright the sun out of his wonted course,
Africa I will die thy Tawny sands in blood,
and set a purple on thy Sunburnt face,
This is the day thy terror first began,
Before great Muly and Sebastian,
Drive on, and I will lackey by thy side,
these Christian Lords I trust will take no scorn,
When Muli-hamet bears them company.
Away,

body.stage:
Exeunt.
Two Trumpets sound at either end: Enter Mully hamet and Antonio.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Second thy son what ever thou best that callest, and with thy proud importance greet our ears,

sp.speaker: Muly ham.
sp.l: What African or warlike Portugal,
comes forth to answer.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Muly Hamet I.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.l: Antonio.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: The same proud Moore: that proud Portugal.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.l: Where is sebastian: he comes not forth
Himself to answer me.

body.stage: Enter sebastian: Mahamet and the traine.

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: Here Muly hamet, here stout African
What wouldst thou Hamet with the portuguese
Where is abdelmeleek thy proud haughty brother.

sp.speaker: Abdel.
sp.l: here brave sebastian king of portugal,

sp.speaker: sebast,
sp.l: O art thou there: thyself in presence then.
What wouldst thou beg proud abdelmeleck speak,

sp.speaker: abdel.
sp.l: Beg, it is a word I never herd before
yet understand I what thou meanest thereby,
there is not a child of manly Zariks line,
But scorns to Beg of Mahomet himself,
we shall lead fortune with us bound about,
and sell her Bounty as we do our slaves,
we mount her back, and manage her for war,
as we do use to serve Barbarian horse,
and check her with the snaffle and the razins,
We bend her swelling crest, and stop and turn,
as it best like us haughty portugal,

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: we will spur your Jennet lusty african
and with our pistols, we will prick her pampered sides
until with yakking she do break her girths,
and fling her gallant rider in the field,
and say proud Moore: that so said Portugal.

sp.speaker: Abdel.
sp.l: Thy words do sound of honour christian king,
Which makes me therefore pity thee the more,
And sorrow that thy valour should be sunk,
In such a vast unknown sea of Arms.
Where thy bid courage, cannot bear that sail,
That thy proud haughty spirit would gladly have,
Therefore Sebastian cast aside these arms
that thou unjustly bears against thy friend,
and leave that traitor that but trains thee on,
Into the Jaws of thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.l: Brave young Sebastian king of Portugal,
and Don Antonio hear me gallant Lords,
Muly Mahamet, but you are in presence,
Would think himself damned everlastingly,
But to hold wrack with so base a slave,
Whose coward melting soul for very fear,
Comes frighted up and down within his bosom,
and fain would find a Message from his breast,
So Daunted with the terror of our arms,
That he is mad his soldiers will not fly,
That with some colour he might turn his back.
Seest thou the power, of africa in my hand
Like furious lightening in the hand of Jove,
to dash thy pride, and like a raging storm,
to tear those Turkish flags that spread their silks,
upon the strands of peaceful africa,
and quakest not slave: with terror of the same.

sp.speaker: Hamet.
sp.l: Dare but my brothers Bastard and a slave,
that should have kneeled at Abdelmelechs feet,
send these proud threats from his audacious lips.

sp.speaker: Maha.
sp.l: Down Dog: and crouch before the feet
Of great Morocco: of mighty Fesse:
But why vouchsafe I language to this Slave,
Hear me Sebastian: thou brave Portuguese,
I Mulihamet king of mighty Sus,
whose Countries bounds and limits do extend
From mighty Atlas: over all those Lands,
that stretch themselves to the Atlantic Sea,
And look upon Canaries wealthy Isles,
And on the west to Gibraltar's Straights,
those fruitful For-lands, and the famous towns
Assure sebastian king of portugal
Most glorious and triumphant victory.

sp.speaker: Abdel.
sp.l: Hear me Sebastian, hear me youthful king?
and abdelmelech will receive thee yet,
And clip thee in the arms of gentle peace.
forsake this tyrant and join hands with me,
and at thy pleasure quietly possess,
The towns thou holdest in africa at this day,
Aginer, Zahanra, Seuta, Penon, Melilla,
Which Muly Mahamet, will dispossess thee of,
If by thy means he should obtain the day.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Say Abdelmeleck, tell me wilt thou yet
Dismiss thy power, break these rebellious arms,
Which now thou bearest against the king of Fesse,
and great Sebastian king of Portugal:
Yet of Mahamet, will obtain thy life.

sp.speaker: Hamet.
sp.l: Look on the power that Abdelmeleck brings,
Of brave resolved Turks, and valiant Moors,
Approved Alarkes: puissant Argolets,
as numberless as be these African sands,
and turn thee then and leave thy petty power,
the succour failing you expect from spain,
and bow thy knees for mercy Portugal,

sp.speaker: anto.
sp.l: Our very slaves our Negroes, Muleteers,
able to give you Battle in the field,
Then think of those that you must cope withal,
The Portugal and his approved power.
Muly-Mahamet and his valiant Moors
The Irish Marquis, Stukley and his troops,
Of warlike Germans and Italians,
Aluares, Ceasar, Menesis and avero,
Proud abdelmeleck, kneel and beg for grace,

sp.speaker: abbel.
sp.l: Then proud Sebastian I deny all means.

sp.speaker: Maha.
sp.l: Therefore Mahamet and Sebastian farewell.

body.stage:
Excursions.
Enter Sebastian, antonio, auaro and Stukly In counsell together.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Advise us Lords if we this present night,
shall pass the river of Mezaga here,
Upon whose sundry banks our tents are pitched,
Or stay the morning Fresh approaching sun.

sp.speaker: aue.
sp.l: In my opinion let us not remove,
The night is dark the river passing deep,
And we ourselves and all my troops my Lord,
Exceeding weary with the last days march.

sp.speaker: anto.
sp.l: My Lord Abero councils well methinks.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: What is your opinion Marquis of Ireland?

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: My Lord might I persuade neither tonight,
Nor in the morning should ye cross the river:
Our men are weak, the enemy is strong,
our men are feeble, they in perfect health,
Beside it is better discipline I judge,
To let them seek us here, than we them there,
Considering what advantage may be had,
Against them that first attempt to pass the river,
Again, on this side whatsoever fall
We have Larassa and Morocco both,
strong towns of succour to retire unto,

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Retire unto, talks stukely of retreat
are you invested with a Marquess name,
Graced with the title of a fiery spirit,
Renowned, and talkest so of fortitude?
and lurks there in your breast so mean a thought,
Can there issue from your lips a term,
So base and beggarly, as that of flight,
I rather thought that Stukley would have said,
We bait here and are not swift enough,
In seeking fit time to begin the fight.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Conceit me not Sebastian at the worst,
You craved my counsel and in that respect,
I speak my conscience if you like it not,
Condemn me not therefore of cowardice,
For what I said was as a faithful friend,
Careful we should embrace the safest course.
But as I am Tom Stukley, and a captain,
Never known yet to stand in fear of death,
Rise when you will his foot that is the foremost,
His sword that soonest drawn my foot and sword,
Shall be as forward and as quickly drawn:
Nay do but follow and I will lead the way,
I will be the first shall wade up to the chin,
Or pass Mezagas channel, and the first
Shall give assault unto the enemy,
So little do I fear the extremest brunt,
Or hardest fortune that attends on war.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.l: To arms brave king, to arms courageous Lords,
Bright crested victory doth waft us on,
And all advantage that may be had,
Offer to fill our hands with wished spoil,
and cheer our hearts with endless happiness,
False Abdelmeleck mortally is sick,
For fear I think that we shall vanquish him,
his soldiers mutinies, and his best friends,
Begin to waver and mistrust the cause,
Of which three thousand of his stout Alarks,
men very expert with the shield and Lance,
This night are fled to uswho likewise tell,
Of many thousands more that will revolt,
Were we but ordered once within the field,
I dare assure ye had not crossed the river,
As now the day break calls us to labour,
So that there might be expeditious means,
For such as do affect us to depart,
Half abdelmelecks, army would forsake him.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: No longer great Mahamet will we linger,
We gave direction by our pioneers,
So soon as any beams of light appeared
Within the East: to settle to their work,
and make our passage smother through the ford,
and least they loiter we ourself in person,
Will overlook them that by ten a clock,
Within yonder plain adjacent to Alcazar,
The lot of happy Fortune may be cast,
Come Lords and each unto his several charges.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.l: Bravely resolved, myself will follow you,
and so it happen that Mahamet speed,
I wreck not who or turk or christian bleed.

body.stage: Exeunt. The Trumpets sounding to the Bataile. Enter abdelmeleck and sebastian, fighting: after them againe, Muly Mahamet, and Muly hamet: then antonio: with some other passing away, then they retired back, abdelmeleck alone in the battell.

sp.speaker: Abdel.
sp.l: Fetch me one drop of water any man:
and I will give him Taneers wealthy Town,
The sands of africa, are so parching hot,
That when our blood doth light upon the earth,
The drops do seeth like Caldrons as they stand,
Tell Made like Ink it cleave unto the hoof,
Of our fierce Jennets: which sunk under neath us,
Overcome with heat: some water, water howe.

sp.speaker: soul.
sp.l: My Lord you have been very lately sick.
Running in haste.
and scarcely yet recovered your disease,
Withdraw yourself out of the murdering press:
Hazzard not so the safety of us all.

sp.speaker: abdel.
sp.l: Go slave and preach unto the droughty earth
Persuade it if thou canst to shun the rain,
My soul to death is thirsty for revenge,
Rush through the ranks, let the proud christians know,
That abdelmeleck vows their overthrow.

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: The sun so heats our armour with his beams,
that it doth burn and sear our very flesh,
that when we would stretch out our arms to strike,
Our parched sinews crack like parchments scrolls,
and fly in sunder that our arms stands out
stiff as our Lances, and our swords fall down,
and stick their envious points into the earth:

sp.speaker: Muli mah.
sp.l: there never yet was such a heat before,
Since Phaiton set this universe on fire,
that the earth fearing he had lived again.
and got into the chariot of the sun,
Opens her wide mouth like a gaping wall,
Hastily.

sp.speaker: sebast.
sp.l: Muli mahamet say, how stands the day?

sp.speaker: muli mah.
sp.l: Fly, fly Sebastian: for the foe prevails,
Dugall, who led five thousand men of war,
Is now revolted to the enemy,
farewell Sebastian, this our latest night,
I will assay to save myself by flight.

body.stage: Enter a companie set vpon sebastian, and kill him, they go out, enter a soldier bringing in abdelmeleck on his back, muli-mahamet following.

sp.speaker: muli-hamet.
sp.l: I ever feared that my courageous Brother,
would wade so far: into this storm of war,
that he would be too lavish of his person.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: My Lord be died not by the dint of sword:
But, being overcome with toil and heat,
Not well recovered of his dangerous sickness,
Sunk down for faintness, and gave up his soul.

sp.speaker: Muly
sp.l: In the secrets manner that thou canst devise,
Convey his royal course into our tent,
for if his death should once be blown abroad,
It were a means to overthrow the day.

body.stage:
Enter a souldior running.
Exit soldier carrying his body.

sp.l: Speak slave who has the advantage of the day.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Our valiant turks, and Moors have got the field
Sebastyan slain: Muly Mahamet fled,
And abdelmeleck crowned with victory.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.l: Shine glorious sun, and bear unto the west
News of our conquest: and fright those that dwell,
Under our feet with Terror of our name,
Reign in thy fiery palfraies yet awhile,
And trot them softly on those airy planks,
To look upon the glory of the day.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Don Antonio, disguised like a priest fearefully Lookeing about him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Ah poor Antonio, which way canst thou take,
But dreadful horror dogs thee at the heels?
Sebastian slain, Muly Mahamet fled:
All Portugal brave Infantries slain,
and not a man of mark or note alive.
Thou glad to hide thee in a priests disguise,
Thy Chaplain, that came with thee to the war,
and in this battle likewise lost his life.
Heaven (be thou pleased) this yet may stand in stead:
If not, thy will then be accomplished.

body.stage: Enter three or foure Turkish Soldiors.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul.
sp.l: See, here is a priest yet left alive.
Sirrah, come hither, how hast thou escaped;
What, shall we kill him?

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: No, kill him not, first let us ransack him.
What hast thou Sirrah, that may save thy life?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: All that I have my friends, I will give ye freely,
So it may please ye but to save my life?
Which to destroy will do ye little good.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: Come then be brief, let us see, what hast thou?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: This purse containeth all the coin I have,
These Bracelets my dead Lord bestowed on me,
That if I scaped, I might remember him,
In my devotions and my daily prayers.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: Whose priest wast thou?

sp.speaker: anto.
sp.l: Ferdinands. duke of Aueros.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: Well listen fellows it will do us little good
To kill him, when we may make benefit
By selling of him to be some man's slave:
And now I call to mind the wealthy Moore,
amaleck that dwells here in the Fesse, He will give as much
as any man, how say ye shall it be so.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: No better counsel can be.

sp.speaker: anto.
sp.l: Thy will O God be done, what ever become of me
Thus of Alcazars battle in one day
three kings at once did lose their hapless lives.
Your gentle favour must we needs entreat,
For rude presenting such a royal fight,
Which more imagination must supply:
Than all our utmost strength can reach unto.
Suppose the Soldiers,who you saw surprised,
the poor dismayed prince antonio:
Have sold him to the wealthy Moore they talked of,
And that such time as needs must be allowed,
already he hath past in servitude,
Sit now and see unto our stories end,
all those mishaps that this poor Prince attend.

body.stage: After antonio's going out Enter Muly hamet with victorie.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: The certain number that can yet be found,
and of the christian Lords,
The Duke of averro: and the bish. of Cambra, and Portua
The Irish Marquis, Stukley, Count Tanara,
two hundred of the chief nobility of Portugal,
and muly Hamet, passing of the ford,
Of swift Larissa to escape by flight,
His horse and he both drowned in the river.

sp.speaker: muly.
sp.l: See that the Body of Sebastian,
Have christian and kingly Burial,
after his country manner for in life,
A Braver spirit never lived upon the same,
and let the christian bodies be interred,
for muly-mahamet: let his skin be flayed,
from off the flesh: from foot unto the head,
and stuffed within: and so be borne about,
through all the parts of our Dominions,
to terrify the like that shall pursue,
to lift their swords against their sovereign.
And in Memorial of this victory,
for ever after be this fourth of August,
Kept holy to the service of our gods,
Through all our Kingdoms and dominions.

body.stage: Enter Stukley faint and wearie being wounded, with him Vernon.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Come noble Vernon that I meet you here,
Were the day far more bloody than it is,
our hope more desperate and our lives beset,
With greater peril than we can devise,
Yet should I laugh at death and think this field,
but as an easy bed to sleep upon.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O master Stukley since there now remains,
No way but one, and life must here have end,
Pardon my speech, if in a word or two,
Whilst here we breath us, I discharge my soul.
I must confess, your presence I have shunned,
Not that I hate you but because thereby,
That grief which I did study to forget,
Was still renewed, and therefore when we met,
In Ireland, Spain, and at the last in Rome,
and that I saw I could no way direct,
My course but always you were in my way,
I thought if Europe I forsook that then,
We should be far enough disjoined but lo,
Even here in Africa we are met again,
and now there is no parting but by death.

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: And then I hope that we shall meet in heaven,
Why master Uernon In our birth we two,
Were so ordained to be of one self heart,
to love one woman, breath one country air,
And now at last as we have sympathized,
In our affections lead one kind of life,
So now we both shall die one kind of death,
In which let this our special comfort be,
That though this parched earth of Barbary,
Drink no more English blood but of us twain,
yet with this blood of ours the blood of kings,
shall be commixed, and with their fame our fame
shall be eternized in the mouths of men.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Forgive me then my former fond conceits,
And ere we die let us embrace like friends,

sp.speaker: stuk.
sp.l: Forgive me rather that must die before,
I can requite the friendship you have shown,
So this is all the will and testament,
That we can make our bodies we bequeath,
to earth from whence they came our souls to heaven,
But for a passing bell to toll our knell,
Ourselves will play the sextons and our swords,
shall ring our farewell on the burganets,
Of these blood thirsty and uncivil turks.

body.stage: Enter foure or fiue Italian souldiers, They lay hands on him.

sp.l: See where he is lay hands upon him sirs,

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Soldiers what mean ye? will you mutinies?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He is your Leader do you seek his life?
To lead us to destruction, but if he
had kept his Oath he swore unto the Pope,
we had been safe in Ireland, where now
we perish here in Africa but before
we taste of death, we vow to see him dead.
then brave Italians stab him to the heart,
That hath so wickedly behaved your lives,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: First villains you shall triumph in my death,
and either kill me else or set him free.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: Hear we you bloody villains.
Stab him soldiers.

body.stage: Vernon fights with some of them to saue Stukly and is slaine of them, in the meane while the rest stab Stukley

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: O have you slain my friend.
Yet doth he prate.

sp.speaker: Stuk.
sp.l: England farewell: what fortune never yet,
Did cross Tom Stukley in, to show her frown,
By treason suffers him to be overthrown.
